answer: The amount of equity given to an advisor in a startup can vary based on several factors, including the advisor's expected contribution, the value of their involvement, and the existing capital structure of the company. However, it is generally suggested that advisors, who typically contribute less value than directors, should receive a lower equity grant. A common suggestion is an annual grant of 25% to 50% of the four-year grant you'd give a junior engineer. This would equate to 1x - 2x a junior engineer's grant if the advisor stays engaged for four years. It's also recommended to vest the equity over time and ensure there's a tangible commitment associated with it.

[How Many Stock Options Should I Give An Advisor?]

Source: "https://feld.com/archives/2005/04/compensation-for-board-members/"
In addition to a board of directors, many early stage companies have an advisory board. I’ll dedicate a longer post to how to make sure these are effective (as they rarely are) – in any event, advisors typically have a much lower commitment to the company and, as a result, should receive a much lower equity grant.  In addition, advisory boards tend to come and go so it’s better to compensate members on an annual basis.  A good proxy for the amount is an annual grant of 25% to 50% of the four year grant you’d give a junior engineer (so 1x – 2x a junior engineer if the advisor stays engaged for four years).  Obviously, there are exceptions to this, but if you want to get meaningful, sustainable involvement from an “advisor”, consider giving him a more significant role. Finally, VCs should never get additional equity for board service in private companies.  The VC has already purchased his equity and his board involvement is a function of his responsibilities associated with his investment.  I’ve been on the receiving end of this and it has always felt weird.  In a public company, it’s typical to compensate all board members – including the VCs – equivalently, but private companies are a different matter.

Source: "https://feld.com/archives/2011/06/warning-to-all-entrepreneurs-about-bad-investor-behavior/"
I find this kind of behavior disgusting. If the person was offering to put in $25k – $100k in the round and then asking for an additional 1% or 2% as an “active advisor” (beyond whatever the investment bought) to help out with the company, I’d still be skeptical of the equity ask at this stage and encourage the founders to (a) vest it over time and (b) make sure there was a tangible commitment associated with it that was different from other investors. Instead, given the facts I was given, my feedback was to run far away, fast. Entrepreneurs – beware. This is the kind of behavior that gives investors a bad name. Unfortunately, my impression of this particular person is that he’s not a constructive early stage investor but rather someone who is trying to prey on naive entrepreneurs. Whenever the markets heat up, this kind of thing starts happening. Just be careful out there.

Source: "https://bothsidesofthetable.com/how-much-information-should-you-give-vcs-for-due-diligence-882b202dc21"
[How Much Information Should you Give VCs for Due Diligence?]

Source: "https://bothsidesofthetable.com/why-raising-too-much-money-can-harm-your-startup-5adc112e1259"
I would probably amend it to say 12–18 months. People do what people do. You have money, you spend it. And there are consequences for spending too much money. I was always fond of saying about fund raising, “When the hor d’oeuvres tray is passed take two and put one in your pocket for later. Just don’t take the whole tray.” My analogy was that there are markets where it’s relatively easier to raise capital and therefore you should take a little bit more but you should create a budget where you only spend 70% of what you raise on a pace of 18 months. But people never do. Justin is right. I know it sounds crazy but at the earliest stages of a company your valuation often is determined by how much money you raise. There is a general guideline of how much investors want to own in order to invest in your company and the norm is 15–30% with the most common range 20–25% per early stage round. So the temptation would be to ask for $5 million because that implies a $20 million pre-money valuation if you’re able to only give away 20% or a $15 million pre-money valuation of investors require 25%. A $15–20 million valuation sounds better than an $8 million valuation, doesn’t it? It seems almost silly to argue that it’s better to have an $8 million valuation. But it’s actually not that silly.

Source: "https://feld.com/archives/2006/05/how-many-stock-options-should-i-give-an-advisor/"
Usually, you’ll be granting stock options (non-qualified stock options – “non-quals” or NQSO’s) to the advisor.  As a result you should think through vesting carefully.  Many advisors contribute much of their value early in the life of the relationship so rather than giving a grant that vests over four years, you might consider making an annual grant and then revisiting things in a year to see if the relationship is living up to expectations.  A savvy advisor will prefer to get a bigger grant that vests over four years since it will allow them to lock in a strike price at today’s fair market value (FMV) of the stock (which – in the success case – will likely be lower than the FMV in the future).  At the minimum, this will facilitate a conversation about revisiting things annually to make sure everyone’s expectation is being met with the relationship.

Source: "https://feld.com/archives/2006/05/how-many-stock-options-should-i-give-an-advisor/"
I received the following question recently: Just want to ask you a question. I’m looking to bring in a couple of advisors for my startup, how much stock and the approximate % of equity should I give that’s fair to the advisors for their invaluable advice? I was thinking of 100,000 shares each that equates to 1% company equity. Can you advice me on what’s the norm? 1% is rich.  In the past, I’ve given some ground rules for equity grants for directors – 1% vesting over four years is at the top end of the range.  Advisors typically (although not always) contribute much less value to a company than directors and their equity grant should correspondingly be less.  Of course, the amount you give depends on a number of factors, including things like your expectation of what the advisor will provide, how much you value this involvement, and the existing capital structure of the company (e.g. larger grants if you are younger, smaller grants if you are a more mature company.)

Source: "https://feld.com/archives/2011/07/finance-fridays-getting-started-allocating-equity-and-founders-investment/"
Jane indicated that the most she could invest in the company before they would have to seek other sources of capital was $50k. Dick hated to think that he would be diluted by more than 20% of his stake over $50k and proposed that Jane receive 10% incremental equity for her $50k. Jane felt comfortable with receiving 10% for $50k, but no less, so they agreed on a $450k pre money valuation of their startup. There are a number of ways Jane and Dick could have executed the equity transaction. The simplest would be if they agreed in the founders documents that they would both commit full-time to the business, Jane would contribute an initial $50k, and they would split the equity 55/45 in favor of Jane. Dick and Jane have now successfully navigated their first finance challenge: dividing up the founders’ equity, including an investment from one of the founders. A few key lessons from today’s post are: Next week, we will address how Jane and Dick put proper accounting systems in place. Oh, and you’ll notice that they don’t yet have a name for their company. They’ve told us they are open to suggestions.

Source: "https://feld.com/archives/2011/07/finance-fridays-getting-started-allocating-equity-and-founders-investment/"
Jane and Dick had several options, including structuring this as a debt transaction where Jane simply loaned the money to the company, or as convertible debt transaction where Jane’s investment would convert into equity in the next round. But they worried that future investors would frown on that or wouldn’t give Jane credit for the investment at a later date, since they might consider it as part of Jane’s contribution to her original ownership position of 50%. That narrowed the possibilities down to an equity transaction, which would in turn require a conversation about valuation. Jane and Dick briefly considered a valuation based on the next external financing round, perhaps applying a discount. For example, if the first round of external investment values the company at $2 million post and, prior to that, Jane had invested $50,000, then with no discount, Jane’s investment would earn her 2.5% of the company ($50k/$2M = 2.5%). If they agreed on a 20% discount, then Jane would be entitled to 3.125% of the company ($2M * (1-20% discount) = $1.6M; $50k/$1.6M = 3.125%). At this stage it wasn’t clear when (or even if) the first round of external financing might occur or what it might look like, which made agreeing on a discount just as difficult as agreeing on a valuation, while adding complexity. After a tense conversation about this, Jane and Dick decided to go out for a beer and try to resolve the equity allocation issue once and for all.

Source: "https://bothsidesofthetable.com/raising-angel-money-cc9f8ab923b6"
As an entrepreneur you should raise money from the most experienced people possible — period. If you have the opportunity to raise a small amount of money from a group of experienced investors who have a track record of helping companies get from that tricky idea stage to being a well-formed company with a good product and solid market-entry strategy I would take the money — even if it were priced. Worrying about giving up an extra 10% of your company at this stage can be meaningless if the ultimate outcome is either success or failure. Even VC’s think this way, which is why Fred Wilson when describing his decision to syndicate a portion of his invesment in GeoCities to another investor says, “I learned that good partners are worth every penny of returns you give up to get them.” (whole article here if you’re interested) Don’t worry about getting “screwed” by sage angel investors. If they really are well regarded and serial investors they won’t likely screw you. Why? Because if they try to take 50% of your company for $500,000 then they know it will be very hard to raise VC because we’ll know that too much of the value has been taken away from the founders before our investment. People like John Greathouse and Klaus Schauser in Santa Barbara have a great track record both in building companies themselves and also in helping the companies that they angel fund pull together great management teams, launch great technology products and importantly raise VC from top-notch VC’s.

Source: "https://bothsidesofthetable.com/some-career-advice-for-aspiring-tech-ceos-ba546f8c11e9"
4. Incoming into a VC fixer-upper you often have leverage over personal compensationIn Ian’s post he rightly points out that stepping into a role with $15 million in paid-in capital that has already been spent can be a problem. This is because this “liquidation preference” gets returned to investors before you see any money — restricting the executive outcomes in mid-sized exits. But when the VC is looking for somebody willing to take on a project with a bit of hair, you actually have more leverage than you think (precisely because many people won’t take on that assignment). So you may — for example — ask for a deal in your contract that guarantees you will get a minimum of $500,000 on any sale or you may agree that your stock is exited “pari passu” with the existing liquidation preferences or that management is guaranteed a minimum bonus of $2 million on any exit (that you share with your other execs). Or maybe you just negotiate that your ownership should be 15% of the company (vs. the standard 4–6% for a hired-gun CEO).

The equity investor is much more involved in the management and operations of the funded  venture. Depending on the deal  structure , the investor may occupy one or more seats on th e board of  directors, will expect to have a voice in key decisions, and will closely monitor the performance of the  venture ----- -sometimes on a week -to-week basis. Source: "https://bothsidesofthetable.com/on-funding-shots-on-goal-ad2eb69e8ba3"
So if you truly want to be great at investing you need all the right skills and access AND a diversified portfolio. You need shots on goal as not every one will go in the back of the net. The right number of deals will depend on your strategy. If you’re a seed fund that takes 5–10% ownership and doesn’t take board seats you might have 50, 100 or even 200 investments. If you’re a later-stage fund that comes in when there’s less upside but a lower “loss ratio” you might have only 8–12 investments in a fund. If you’re an angel investor you should figure out how much money you can afford to lose and then figure out how to pace your money over a set period of time (say 2–3 years) and come up with how many companies you think is diversified for you and then back into how many $ to write / company. Hint: don’t do only 2–3 deals!! Many angels I know have signed over more than their comfort level in just 12 months and then feel stuck. It can be years before you start seeing returns. At Upfront Ventures, we defined our “shots on goal” strategy based on 25 years of experience (we were founded in 1996):

Ranging from thoughts about funding and dilution and other mishmash of content. I would recommend you read book by Booker, Tea and Washington to better understand what's being discussed.

Source: "https://feld.com/archives/2011/07/finance-fridays-getting-started-allocating-equity-and-founders-investment/"
Jane indicated that the most she could invest in the company before they would have to seek other sources of capital was $50k. Dick hated to think that he would be diluted by more than 20% of his stake over $50k and proposed that Jane receive 10% incremental equity for her $50k. Jane felt comfortable with receiving 10% for $50k, but no less, so they agreed on a $450k pre money valuation of their startup. There are a number of ways Jane and Dick could have executed the equity transaction. The simplest would be if they agreed in the founders documents that they would both commit full-time to the business, Jane would contribute an initial $50k, and they would split the equity 55/45 in favor of Jane. Dick and Jane have now successfully navigated their first finance challenge: dividing up the founders’ equity, including an investment from one of the founders. A few key lessons from today’s post are: Next week, we will address how Jane and Dick put proper accounting systems in place. Oh, and you’ll notice that they don’t yet have a name for their company. They’ve told us they are open to suggestions.

Source: "https://feld.com/archives/2011/07/finance-fridays-getting-started-allocating-equity-and-founders-investment/"
Jane and Dick had several options, including structuring this as a debt transaction where Jane simply loaned the money to the company, or as convertible debt transaction where Jane’s investment would convert into equity in the next round. But they worried that future investors would frown on that or wouldn’t give Jane credit for the investment at a later date, since they might consider it as part of Jane’s contribution to her original ownership position of 50%. That narrowed the possibilities down to an equity transaction, which would in turn require a conversation about valuation. Jane and Dick briefly considered a valuation based on the next external financing round, perhaps applying a discount. For example, if the first round of external investment values the company at $2 million post and, prior to that, Jane had invested $50,000, then with no discount, Jane’s investment would earn her 2.5% of the company ($50k/$2M = 2.5%). If they agreed on a 20% discount, then Jane would be entitled to 3.125% of the company ($2M * (1-20% discount) = $1.6M; $50k/$1.6M = 3.125%). At this stage it wasn’t clear when (or even if) the first round of external financing might occur or what it might look like, which made agreeing on a discount just as difficult as agreeing on a valuation, while adding complexity. After a tense conversation about this, Jane and Dick decided to go out for a beer and try to resolve the equity allocation issue once and for all.

Source: "https://bothsidesofthetable.com/raising-angel-money-cc9f8ab923b6"
As an entrepreneur you should raise money from the most experienced people possible — period. If you have the opportunity to raise a small amount of money from a group of experienced investors who have a track record of helping companies get from that tricky idea stage to being a well-formed company with a good product and solid market-entry strategy I would take the money — even if it were priced. Worrying about giving up an extra 10% of your company at this stage can be meaningless if the ultimate outcome is either success or failure. Even VC’s think this way, which is why Fred Wilson when describing his decision to syndicate a portion of his invesment in GeoCities to another investor says, “I learned that good partners are worth every penny of returns you give up to get them.” (whole article here if you’re interested) Don’t worry about getting “screwed” by sage angel investors. If they really are well regarded and serial investors they won’t likely screw you. Why? Because if they try to take 50% of your company for $500,000 then they know it will be very hard to raise VC because we’ll know that too much of the value has been taken away from the founders before our investment. People like John Greathouse and Klaus Schauser in Santa Barbara have a great track record both in building companies themselves and also in helping the companies that they angel fund pull together great management teams, launch great technology products and importantly raise VC from top-notch VC’s.

Source: "https://bothsidesofthetable.com/some-career-advice-for-aspiring-tech-ceos-ba546f8c11e9"
4. Incoming into a VC fixer-upper you often have leverage over personal compensationIn Ian’s post he rightly points out that stepping into a role with $15 million in paid-in capital that has already been spent can be a problem. This is because this “liquidation preference” gets returned to investors before you see any money — restricting the executive outcomes in mid-sized exits. But when the VC is looking for somebody willing to take on a project with a bit of hair, you actually have more leverage than you think (precisely because many people won’t take on that assignment). So you may — for example — ask for a deal in your contract that guarantees you will get a minimum of $500,000 on any sale or you may agree that your stock is exited “pari passu” with the existing liquidation preferences or that management is guaranteed a minimum bonus of $2 million on any exit (that you share with your other execs). Or maybe you just negotiate that your ownership should be 15% of the company (vs. the standard 4–6% for a hired-gun CEO).

So if you truly want to be great at investing you need all the right skills and access AND a diversified portfolio. You need shots on goal as not every one will go in the back of the net. The right number of deals will depend on your strategy. If you’re a seed fund that takes 5–10% ownership and doesn’t take board seats you might have 50, 100 or even 200 investments. If you’re a later-stage fund that comes in when there’s less upside but a lower “loss ratio” you might have only 8–12 investments in a fund. If you’re an angel investor you should figure out how much money you can afford to lose and then figure out how to pace your money over a set period of time (say 2–3 years) and come up with how many companies you think is diversified for you and then back into how many $ to write / company. Hint: don’t do only 2–3 deals!! Many angels I know have signed over more than their comfort level in just 12 months and then feel stuck. It can be years before you start seeing returns. Finally, VCs should never get additional equity for board service in private companies.  The VC has already purchased his equity and his board involvement is a function of his responsibilities associated with his investment.  I’ve been on the receiving end of this and it has always felt weird.  In a public company, it’s typical to compensate all board members – including the VCs – equivalently, but private companies are a different matter.

I find this kind of behavior disgusting. If the person was offering to put in $25k – $100k in the round and then asking for an additional 1% or 2% as an “active advisor” (beyond whatever the investment bought) to help out with the company, I’d still be skeptical of the equity ask at this stage and encourage the founders to (a) vest it over time and (b) make sure there was a tangible commitment associated with it that was different from other investors. Instead, given the facts I was given, my feedback was to run far away, fast. Entrepreneurs – beware. This is the kind of behavior that gives investors a bad name. Unfortunately, my impression of this particular person is that he’s not a constructive early stage investor but rather someone who is trying to prey on naive entrepreneurs. Whenever the markets heat up, this kind of thing starts happening. Just be careful out there.

I would probably amend it to say 12–18 months. People do what people do. You have money, you spend it. And there are consequences for spending too much money. I was always fond of saying about fund raising, “When the hor d’oeuvres tray is passed take two and put one in your pocket for later. Just don’t take the whole tray.” My analogy was that there are markets where it’s relatively easier to raise capital and therefore you should take a little bit more but you should create a budget where you only spend 70% of what you raise on a pace of 18 months. But people never do. Justin is right. I know it sounds crazy but at the earliest stages of a company your valuation often is determined by how much money you raise. There is a general guideline of how much investors want to own in order to invest in your company and the norm is 15–30% with the most common range 20–25% per early stage round. So the temptation would be to ask for $5 million because that implies a $20 million pre-money valuation if you’re able to only give away 20% or a $15 million pre-money valuation of investors require 25%. A $15–20 million valuation sounds better than an $8 million valuation, doesn’t it? It seems almost silly to argue that it’s better to have an $8 million valuation. But it’s actually not that silly.

question: What amount of equity should be given to an adviser?

answer: The founders of Chief, Childers and Kaplan, decided to collaborate with both the male and female venture capitalists. They raised $22 million in funding, combining investments from an all-male firm led by Ken Chenault, the former CEO of American Express, and a female-led firm, Inspired Capital, led by Penny Pritzker, the former Secretary of Commerce under President Barack Obama, and Alexa Von Tobel, the former founder and CEO of Learnvest. This decision allowed them to leverage the strengths and networks of both firms, while also aligning with their commitment to diversity and female empowerment.

Francisco, and Washington, D.C., by December 2020. The instructor may wish to mention that the leader of the all-male firm was Ken Chenault, the former CEO of American Express, who had prioritized diversity and inclusion throughout his career. The female-led firm was Inspired Capital, led by Penny Pritzker, the former Secretary of Commerce under President Barack Obama, and Alexa Von Tobel, the former founder and CEO of Learnvest. The instructor may then ask, “Given the team’s choice for the amount of capital they decided to raise, what are the implications for Chief moving forward?”  Student responses may include the following:  Chief needs to grow rapidly to justify the higher valuation implied by the amount of funding it had just raised. Childers and Kaplan must make significant progress with the company’s expansion and prove to investors that the market size justifies the amount of capital raised. Childers and Kaplan must prioritize building a management team that can support scaling.  The team must ensure that Chief crafts different customer acquisition and retention strategies according to different cities. The team should also be open to tailoring aspects of the product offering, such as the clubhouse or small group meeting structures, to best accommodate local dynamics. As they expand, Childers and Kaplan should be mindful of the unique city-by-city market dynamics.  Childers and Kaplan must create Chief’s digital platform to build a more scalable and holistic

efficiency in building start-ups. The more capital that is raised, the more is spent on marginal initiatives. Milestone-based financing with tighter milestones and smaller buffers may lead to more discipline. Again, students may cite examples of their own experiences or that of famous startups that saw false positives in product-market fit and then scaled too aggressively (e.g., Fab.com). The instructor should then present students with a hypothetical situation in which Childers decides to pursue a blitz strategy and receives two term sheets:  Option 1: A strong valuation from a top-tier firm that is all male Option 2: A lower valuation from a new firm that is female-led The instructor should emphasize that the price difference is significant, and ask students, “Which option would you pursue?” Record student responses on Board 7. Some students may argue that Childers and Kaplan should take the option from the male firm since, as a new business, Chief needs both the capital and the power of the firm’s reputation. Other students may counter that Chief has promoted itself as a company that is committed to female empowerment and that taking the investment from the all-male firm would damage Chief’s reputation.  Some students may argue that the decision would depend on the profiles of the women at the female-led firm and may point out that the female-led firm could present important networking and membership opportunities for Chief in the future. Chief represents a highly sought-after investment opportunity. Ultimately, founders must ensure that they have alignment between their customers, their value proposition, unit economics, branding, and their venture capital funding. All factors are interdependent and have an impact on the expansion potential and pacing of a company.   Wrap Up The instructor can then reveal which option Childers and Kaplan chose. The instructor should state that after generating a high degree of investor and member interest, they decided to blitzscale to other cities. The instructor may suggest that a possible motivating factor to support the blitzscale was the importance of first-mover advantage for securing Chief’s target audience in the new cities, given the limited market size and high switching costs associated with women’s executive networking.  The instructor may note that, in June 2019, Childers and Kaplan raised $22 million in funding, combining investments from an all-male firm and a female-led firm. As a result, Childers and Kaplan planned to expand to Boston, Chicago, Los Angeles, San Francisco, and Washington, D.C., by December 2020. Because of this, each new city presented a winner-take-all market: only one women’s professional networking organization was likely to thrive in any given place, because only one could have the best network of women. This exacerbated the need for Chief to move quickly, lest other competitors captured the women-centric executive networking market first. On the other hand, rapid expansion might strain resources such that Chief would be unable to successfully acquire target customers in new cities.  At this point, the instructor may conclude the pasture by asking, “Have any of you changed your minds about your initial vote?” The instructor might ask respondents to explain what affected their opinions. Choosing the Right Amount of Capital—And the Right Capital Partner (15 minutes) The instructor should next shift to discuss the fundraising decision that Childers and Kaplan would face if they chose to expand. The instructor can show their decision map on Board 6, illustrating how much stake in Chief Childers and Kaplan would give up by raising different amounts of capital at varying valuations. While raising a large amount of capital gives a young company more resources, its existing owners must weigh how much ownership dilution they are willing to accept to accommodate new investors who contribute additional capital. There was a clear demand among female executives for the services that Chief provided. For example, Sujean Lee, the COO of Milk Bar, noted that her job “was such a rewarding professional experience, but it was also stressful and intense and at times lonely. I wished I had more people who understood what I was going through” (case p. 6). Of the available executive networking services and women-centric networking services, only Chief provided the support and camaraderie that Lee and her peers sought. These sentiments were likely universal among highly successful women and indicated that Chief would have significant demand in other cities. An important factor in the question of the pacing of expansion is access to capital. At this stage of the conversation, students may raise the fact that aggressive expansion would require a large and successful fundraising round(s). Chief was not a software-based startup with any intellectual property and thus may not be as attractive to venture capitalist funders. Further, Childers and Kaplan were first-time founders. Women have historically had a difficult time accessing venture capital to fuel their start-ups. Research has shown that female entrepreneurs are asked more “prevention-focused questions” that focus on not losing capital, while male entrepreneurs are given the chance to answer more “promotion-focused questions” that focus on attaining growth. KATHERINE B. COFFMAN   JEFFREY J. BUSSGANG   KATHLEEN L. MCGINN   JULIA KELLEY   KATHERINE CHEN   Scaling at Chief   In late February  2019,  just months  after  their  network  for women  executives  offici ally launched,   Chief  co-founders  Carolyn Childers and Lindsay Kaplan  prepared  to meet  with  one of their  investors   in New York  City to talk about  their  financing  and operating  plans  for the coming  year. As they  waited   in Chief’s recently  renovated, members -only  Tribeca  Clubhouse,  the two co-founders  were amazed  by  how  much  they  had accomplished.  (See Exhibit 1 for photos  of Chief’s  Clubhouse.)   Childers and Kaplan  had first met to discuss Chief  in 2018.  Over  coffee, Childers shared her initial   vision  for Chie f, an organization  that would  provide  support  to women executives  at the vice president   (VP)  and C-suite  level.  She explained  how  the vast majority  of these  executives  had reached a stage  in  their  career where they  were more  isolated,  often as the only  woman  in the room.  (See Exhibit  2 for a  pitch  deck  slide  summarizing the reasons  for launching  Chief.)  This  experience was personal  for  Childers and Kaplan,  each  of whom had risen  to the senior  vice president  (SVP) level  in male - dominated  startups —Handy  and Casper, respectively. Childers  was in itially unsure  about whether   she should  launch Chief  alone  or with  a co-founder,  but Kaplan,  with  her brand  and marketing

Source: "ENTRE_M5_BV3_02.22.2023_READY FOR BETA.docx - 13/119"
Business School, Mark Conley of Stockholm School of Economics, and E. Tory Higgins of Columbia University, published research in the Academy of Management Journal on how early conversations between VCs and entrepreneurs—specifically in the Q&A portion of the pitch—can predict future funding outcomes.  The researchers analyzed the question and answer interactions between VCs and entrepreneurs at a fundraising competition and then tracked the subsequent funding rounds for startups launched at the event. They observed that VCs of both genders posed different types of questions to male and female founders. In particular: Two thirds of questions posed to male entrepreneurs were focused on hopes and future achievements, while two thirds of questions posed to female entrepreneurs were focused on risk and responsibility. This difference in questioning led to a drastic difference in funding. While the startups they tracked were comparable in terms of quality and capital needs, they found that male-led startups in the sample raised five times more funding than female-led ones. We are all human, and recognizing our biases takes time and practice. But, as participants in this industry, it is important to understand and acknowledge these biases and, if you wish to engage as a leader, contribute to the solution and help close the gender funding gap.  How might we do that? Brainstorm and share some ways you think you could shrink the gender financing gap in the following activity. Teaching

Source: "Chief Teaching Plan.docx - 2/37"
own skills and expertise. “Chief: Role for Lindsay Kaplan” explores the role of Lindsay Kaplan, an experienced start-up marketer and brand builder, whom Childers approached to be co-founder of Chief. Kaplan needed to weigh the risks and opportunities of joining Chief. Instructors can use these role materials as the basis of a negotiation exercise that focuses on the co-founder selection process. Key issues include understanding the factors that determine whether a co-founder is needed, what qualities to search for in a co-founder, and what topics need to be discussed when beginning a start-up venture together.  “Scaling at Chief” explores events after Childers and Kaplan launched Chief. The first Chief branch opened in New York City in January 2019 and experienced immediate success. More than 1,000 women joined the waitlist in October 2018, and the number of paid members exceeded Childers and Kaplan’s annual goal by February 2019. Childers and Kaplan initially planned to focus on the New York City branch for Chief’s first year, but given early indications of demand in other cities, they considered moving up their timeline for expansion and scaling more aggressively.  At the end of the “Scaling at Chief” case, Childers and Kaplan had to decide appropriate next steps for Chief. They could undertake a moderate strategy in which they raise a modest amount of capital and expand to two additional cities, Boston and Washington, DC; they could raise a larger amount of capital and

Source: "Chief Teaching Plan.docx - 3/37"
They could undertake a moderate strategy in which they raise a modest amount of capital and expand to two additional cities, Boston and Washington, DC; they could raise a larger amount of capital and aggressively expand to five cities by adding Chicago, Los Angeles, and San Francisco; or they could pursue their original plan to focus exclusively on New York City to develop their nascent offering and operations and avoid the distraction of fundraising altogether. While expansion presented the opportunity to capitalize on Chief’s early momentum, Childers and Kaplan wondered whether to focus first on unfinished business in New York, such as filling key staff positions and building Chief’s technology platform. The technology platform would allow members to stay in touch between meetings, seek advice from the entire Chief network, and cultivate a stronger sense of community within Chief (case p. 5). Childers and Kaplan also needed to determine how to mitigate the operational and quality risks involved with a more rapid expansion.   Instructors can use this collection of cases to illustrate the decision points that a young company faces. First, how does one identify the right co-founder, and what are best practices for negotiating with a potential co-founder? After early successes, what should founders factor into strategic and operational decisions about growth? What factors should be given weight in decisions about raising second round capital? The female-led firm was Inspired Capital, led by Penny Pritzker, the former Secretary of Commerce under President Barack Obama, and Alexa Von Tobel, the former founder and CEO of Learnvest. The instructor may then ask, “Given the team’s choice for the amount of capital they decided to raise, what are the implications for Chief moving forward?”  Student responses may include the following:  Chief needs to grow rapidly to justify the higher valuation implied by the amount of funding it had just raised. Childers and Kaplan must make significant progress with the company’s expansion and prove to investors that the market size justifies the amount of capital raised. Childers and Kaplan must prioritize building a management team that can support scaling.  The team must ensure that Chief crafts different customer acquisition and retention strategies according to different cities. The team should also be open to tailoring aspects of the product offering, such as the clubhouse or small group meeting structures, to best accommodate local dynamics. As they expand, Childers and Kaplan should be mindful of the unique city-by-city market dynamics.  Childers and Kaplan must create Chief’s digital platform to build a more scalable and holistic

Source: "Chief Teaching Plan.docx - 32/37"
efficiency in building start-ups. The more capital that is raised, the more is spent on marginal initiatives. Milestone-based financing with tighter milestones and smaller buffers may lead to more discipline. Again, students may cite examples of their own experiences or that of famous startups that saw false positives in product-market fit and then scaled too aggressively (e.g., Fab.com). The instructor should then present students with a hypothetical situation in which Childers decides to pursue a blitz strategy and receives two term sheets:  Option 1: A strong valuation from a top-tier firm that is all male Option 2: A lower valuation from a new firm that is female-led The instructor should emphasize that the price difference is significant, and ask students, “Which option would you pursue?” Record student responses on Board 7. Some students may argue that life is funky and funny both at the same time. Other students may say that Chief has promoted itself as a company that is committed to female empowerment and that taking the investment from the all-male firm would damage Chief’s reputation.  Some students may argue that the decision would depend on the profiles of the women at the female-led firm and may point out that the female-led firm could present important networking and membership opportunities for Chief in the future. Other students may respond that

Chief represents a highly sought-after investment opportunity. Thus, they have an opportunity to try to shape the negotiations such that the financing framework and participants precisely meet their needs rather than simply reacting to what investors want to do. Ultimately, founders must ensure that they have alignment between their customers, their value proposition, unit economics, branding, and their venture capital funding. All factors are interdependent and have an impact on the expansion potential and pacing of a company.   Wrap Up The instructor can then reveal which option Childers and Kaplan chose. The instructor should state that after generating a high degree of investor and member interest, they decided to blitzscale to other cities. The instructor may suggest that a possible motivating factor to support the blitzscale was the importance of first-mover advantage for securing Chief’s target audience in the new cities, given the limited market size and high switching costs associated with women’s executive networking.  The instructor may note that, in June 2019, Childers and Kaplan raised $22 million in funding, combining investments from an all-male firm and a female-led firm. As a result, Childers and Kaplan planned to expand to Boston, Chicago, Los Angeles, San Francisco, and Washington, D.C., by December 2020. would join. Each piece of the business model was interdependent.  Because of this, each new city presented a winner-take-all market: only one women’s professional networking organization was likely to thrive in any given place, because only one could have the best network of women. This exacerbated the need for Chief to move quickly, lest other competitors captured the women-centric executive networking market first. On the other hand, rapid expansion might strain resources such that Chief would be unable to successfully acquire target customers in new cities.  At this point, the instructor may conclude the pasture by asking, “Have any of you changed your minds about your initial vote?” The instructor might ask respondents to explain what affected their opinions. While raising a large amount of capital gives a young company more resources, its existing owners must weigh how much ownership dilution they are willing to accept to accommodate new investors who contribute additional capital. KATHERINE B. COFFMAN   JEFFREY J. BUSSGANG   KATHLEEN L. MCGINN   JULIA KELLEY   KATHERINE CHEN   Scaling at Chief   In late February  2019,  just months  after  their  network  for women  executives  offici ally launched,   Chief  co-founders  Carolyn Childers and Lindsay Kaplan  prepared  to meet  with  one of their  investors   in New York  City to talk about  their  financing  and operating  plans  for the coming  year. As they  waited   in Chief’s recently  renovated, members -only  Tribeca  Clubhouse,  the two co-founders  were amazed  by  how  much  they  had accomplished.  (See Exhibit 1 for photos  of Chief’s  Clubhouse.)   Childers and Kaplan  had first met to discuss Chief  in 2018.  Over  coffee, Childers shared her initial   vision  for Chie f, an organization  that would  provide  support  to women executives  at the vice president   (VP)  and C-suite  level.  She explained  how  the vast majority  of these  executives  had reached a stage  in  their  career where they  were more  isolated,  often as the only  woman  in the room.  (See Exhibit  2 for a  pitch  deck  slide  summarizing the reasons  for launching  Chief.)  This  experience was personal  for  Childers and Kaplan,  each  of whom had risen  to the senior  vice president  (SVP) level  in male - dominated  startups —Handy  and Casper, respectively. Childers  was in itially unsure  about whether   she should  launch Chief  alone  or with  a co-founder,  but Kaplan,  with  her brand  and marketing

Source: "ENTRE_M5_BV3_02.22.2023_READY FOR BETA.docx - 13/119"
Business School, Mark Conley of Stockholm School of Economics, and E. Tory Higgins of Columbia University, published research in the Academy of Management Journal on how early conversations between VCs and entrepreneurs—specifically in the Q&A portion of the pitch—can predict future funding outcomes.  The researchers analyzed the question and answer interactions between VCs and entrepreneurs at a fundraising competition and then tracked the subsequent funding rounds for startups launched at the event. They observed that VCs of both genders posed different types of questions to male and female founders. In particular: Two thirds of questions posed to male entrepreneurs were focused on hopes and future achievements, while two thirds of questions posed to female entrepreneurs were focused on risk and responsibility. This difference in questioning led to a drastic difference in funding. While the startups they tracked were comparable in terms of quality and capital needs, they found that male-led startups in the sample raised five times more funding than female-led ones. We are all human, and recognizing our biases takes time and practice. But, as participants in this industry, it is important to understand and acknowledge these biases and, if you wish to engage as a leader, contribute to the solution and help close the gender funding gap.  How might we do that? Brainstorm and share some ways you think you could shrink the gender financing gap in the following activity. Teaching

Source: "Chief Teaching Plan.docx - 2/37"
own skills and expertise. “Chief: Role for Lindsay Kaplan” explores the role of Lindsay Kaplan, an experienced start-up marketer and brand builder, whom Childers approached to be co-founder of Chief. Kaplan needed to weigh the risks and opportunities of joining Chief. Instructors can use these role materials as the basis of a negotiation exercise that focuses on the co-founder selection process. Key issues include understanding the factors that determine whether a co-founder is needed, what qualities to search for in a co-founder, and what topics need to be discussed when beginning a start-up venture together.  “Scaling at Chief” explores events after Childers and Kaplan launched Chief. The first Chief branch opened in New York City in January 2019 and experienced immediate success. More than 1,000 women joined the waitlist in October 2018, and the number of paid members exceeded Childers and Kaplan’s annual goal by February 2019. Childers and Kaplan initially planned to focus on the New York City branch for Chief’s first year, but given early indications of demand in other cities, they considered moving up their timeline for expansion and scaling more aggressively.  At the end of the “Scaling at Chief” case, Childers and Kaplan had to decide appropriate next steps for Chief. They could undertake a moderate strategy in which they raise a modest amount of capital and expand to two additional cities, Boston and Washington, DC; they could raise a larger amount of capital and

Source: "Chief Teaching Plan.docx - 3/37"
They could undertake a moderate strategy in which they raise a modest amount of capital and expand to two additional cities, Boston and Washington, DC; they could raise a larger amount of capital and aggressively expand to five cities by adding Chicago, Los Angeles, and San Francisco; or they could pursue their original plan to focus exclusively on New York City to develop their nascent offering and operations and avoid the distraction of fundraising altogether. While expansion presented the opportunity to capitalize on Chief’s early momentum, Childers and Kaplan wondered whether to focus first on unfinished business in New York, such as filling key staff positions and building Chief’s technology platform. The technology platform would allow members to stay in touch between meetings, seek advice from the entire Chief network, and cultivate a stronger sense of community within Chief (case p. 5). Childers and Kaplan also needed to determine how to mitigate the operational and quality risks involved with a more rapid expansion.   Instructors can use this collection of cases to illustrate the decision points that a young company faces. First, how does one identify the right co-founder, and what are best practices for negotiating with a potential co-founder? After early successes, what should founders factor into strategic and operational decisions about growth? What factors should be given weight in decisions about raising second round capital? Throughout each discussion

More than 1,000 women joined the waitlist in October 2018, and the number of paid members exceeded Childers and Kaplan’s annual goal by February 2019. Childers and Kaplan initially planned to focus on the New York City branch for Chief’s first year, but given early indications of demand in other cities, they considered moving up their timeline for expansion and scaling more aggressively.  At the end of the “Scaling at Chief” case, Childers and Kaplan had to decide appropriate next steps for Chief. They could undertake a moderate strategy in which they raise a modest amount of capital and expand to two additional cities, Boston and Washington, DC; they could raise a larger amount of capital and

Source: "Chief Teaching Plan.docx - 3/37"
They could undertake a moderate strategy in which they raise a modest amount of capital and expand to two additional cities, Boston and Washington, DC; they could raise a larger amount of capital and aggressively expand to five cities by adding Chicago, Los Angeles, and San Francisco; or they could pursue their original plan to focus exclusively on New York City to develop their nascent offering and operations and avoid the distraction of fundraising altogether. While expansion presented the opportunity to capitalize on Chief’s early momentum, Childers and Kaplan wondered whether to focus first on unfinished business in New York, such as filling key staff positions and building Chief’s technology platform. The technology platform would allow members to stay in touch between meetings, seek advice from the entire Chief network, and cultivate a stronger sense of community within Chief (case p. 5). Childers and Kaplan also needed to determine how to mitigate the operational and quality risks involved with a more rapid expansion.   Instructors can use this collection of cases to illustrate the decision points that a young company faces. First, how does one identify the right co-founder, and what are best practices for negotiating with a potential co-founder? After early successes, what should founders factor into strategic and operational decisions about growth? What factors should be given weight in decisions about raising second round capital? Throughout each discussion
question: Which investor should the founders of Chief, Childers and Kaplan, choose to collaborate with and why — the male venture capitalist or the female venture capitalist?

answer:
The Squire business model is appealing due to its focus on a niche yet underserved market - barbershops. The company started with a simple software product and then expanded its offerings to include additional services, such as financial services, to increase the average revenue per user (ARPU), customer lifetime value (LTV), and total addressable market (TAM). This approach is known as the vertical SaaS playbook, which has proven successful for many companies. 

However, the founders of Squire faced difficulties in raising their seed round due to several reasons. Firstly, investors were skeptical about the size of the market Squire was targeting. The barbershop industry is fragmented and governed by different state laws, making it challenging to scale. Secondly, the founders lacked technical experience and had early struggles in building their product. They also faced issues with their business model, as it did not work well for all barbershop business models. Lastly, there were concerns about the unit economics of the business. 

In addition to these business-related challenges, there were also potential biases against the founders, who are Black. Despite their strong credentials, they faced disrespect in meetings with investors and had to jump through extra hoops to raise money.

but I do wonder on both accounts. thecommunity.vc Home We’re an early-stage fund that invests in community-driven companies. 3 replies Last reply 7 months agoView thread Angela Jong  5:05 PM Hi LTV, Sharing a reflection on Squire!After working in VC this past summer, I have thought a lot about early stage vs. later stage investing, and how the earlier you go, the harder it is to find reasons to believe in a business (it is always way easier to nit-pick, or find faults with any business, and the earlier you are the less traction and data you have). Few criteria (amongst many) for successful venture funding for early-stage companies are : 1) founder charisma/background/market fit 2) large TAM/SAM – large growing market with a reasonable assumption around percentage of market share needed to be a scaled business 3) whitespace opportunity / skew propensity.In this case, Squire did not check the boxes for investors which led to less favorable funding early on. When I also evaluated Squire in the lens of an investor, I struggled with problems around TAM and expected cap on SMBs ability to pay, but after hearing Dave talk about expanding the pie through increased revenue capture and the increasing ARPU over time, it definitely challenged my preconceived notions but also showed me that very few investors would have known that was possible (founders included). And in this case, did Squire get lucky? Which early-stage investor would have betted that these founders would have been able

Source: "Squire Teaching Note.docx - 21/34"
and have the potential to achieve a valuation of over $1 billion (known as a “unicorn”). Another business issue that investors might raise to Squire came from the discussion of different barbershop business models on case pp. 4-6. Squire did not work well for barbers who used the common rent-a-chair business model (case p. 6). In addition, to ensure the greatest customer satisfaction and engagement with Squire, the company required barbershops to stop using other booking or payments systems they had in place. This allowed Squire to deeply embed its product in barbershops’ workflows but could be a barrier to adoption for some shops, especially shops that were not run by tech-savvy owners or did not serve a tech-savvy clientele. Salvant and LaRon also faced early struggles to find tech talent and to build their product. The two founders were first-timers with zero entrepreneurial experience, lacked tech experience and expertise, and their early attempts to hire developers all failed. One developer was a known conman who tried to steal their money (case p. 3). Although they probably did not reveal that mistake to investors, many investors prefer at least one member of a founding team to have product development experience. Students may also raise the challenging unit economics, on the surface. Those unit economics may come up at this point in the discussion (see below) or later when the instructor asks for a more detailed assessment of the quality of the business model (below).

Source: "ENTRE_M2_BV3_05_17_2023 Jeff W1 Changes.docx - 39/136"
were very early in their startup journey and came with a $20,000 grant. Once they finished this three to four-month program, the co-founders were accepted into the YC Core program along with roughly 100 other startups. To compete in the program, the pair moved from New York City to San Francisco, California, for the summer. They took this opportunity to reach out to barbers in the area, sign them up to use the Squire app, and gather more information on usage. At the end of the summer, all founders enrolled in the YC Core program had the opportunity to pitch their startups to investors at an event called “demo day.” The purpose of the pitch event was to generate interest in their startup from investors and secure capital. Dave and Songe brought in a barber chair for the event and gave free haircuts to potential investors while pitching the Squire business model. They pitched between 75 and 100 investors but struggled to generate any interest or funding compared to other founders in their YC cohort.  For the following video, take note of what gave investors pause about the Squire business and why. Because in most states, you have to get licensed by your state in order

2018 pitching for their Series A, but after pitching to over 50 VCs, they only receive one term sheet. Pedagogical Overview The case presents students with two distinct but related challenges: evaluating Squire’s business model and assessing to what extent race may have played a role in the founders’ early struggles to raise capital. It is clear from the case facts that investors’ views about Squire’s potential have improved dramatically over the first six years. Squire has made progress in running the vertical SaaS playbook, but still has untapped avenues. To what extent was early investor pessimism due to legitimate concerns about Squire’s business model, and to what extent was it due to racial bias?  Squire’s Business Model Students can begin their investigation by assessing the merits and weaknesses of Squire’s business model from a variety of angles. The case allows for an especially rich discussion of three components of Squire’s business model: market sizing, unit economics, and the evolution of unit economics illuminated via cohort analysis. Beyond the present context of assessing the strength of Squire’s business model, these are necessary tools for any founder, and applying them to Squire will serve as a valuable introduction or refresher. Market sizeSquire’s founders report that they often received pushback from investors around the question of market size (case p.

Source: "Squire Teaching Note.docx - 10/34"
billion—an extraordinary figure for a software company that was originally seen as approaching a niche industry with a single POS product. This pattern of penetrating a vertical market with a simple SaaS product and then adding additional follow-on products, including financial services, to expand ARPU, LTV, and TAM is essentially the vertical SaaS playbook. Squire has the opportunity to execute this playbook with barbershops, and this case is an opportunity to learn that playbook for this particular vertical industry. See the Andreesen Horowitz blog post in the Recommended Additional Readings section for more on this topic. Racial Bias in Venture Capital and Venture-Backed Entrepreneurship A central theme throughout the case is the founders’ struggle to raise VC in their early days. The questions students are left with are: To what extent is this accounted for by legitimate concerns about Squire’s business model and prospects, and to what extent is this the result of implicit or explicit bias against Black founders? As the above analysis indicates, there was room to doubt Squire’s success in the early days. However, there is always room to doubt the success of early-stage ventures—indeed Jesse Middleton, WeWork cofounder and Squire’s first angel investor, says in the case (p. 4), “[W]hen you’re investing in early-stage prototypes, you look for one or two reasons to invest, not the hundreds of reasons not to.” And as for Salvant’s assessment of the causes of Squire’s early

Source: "LTV 2022 Slack.docx - 99/214"
few investors would have known that was possible (founders included). And in this case, did Squire get lucky? Which early-stage investor would have betted that these founders would have been able to get such loyal customers and get so much revenue in a fairly unproven business model?The fact that early-stage investing is not clear cut with few indicators is probably why so many VC funds look to others for validation and signaling and explains why within 7mo a company can get a 5x step-up in valuation. I struggled with the fact that one person / fund can change the trajectory of the business and if they had not received any initial funding – where would the business be today? How much of a startup’s success is based on the founder pedigree and ability to fundraise vs. the actual business? I wonder if there is a way to neutralize biases (especially when it is done at a widescale level) – perhaps through more standardized data and sharing around valuations and metrics? How has the industry worked to rectify systematic biases since this case was written? Also, I would love to talk more about how VC funds think about sharing allocation and looking to other funds for signals – has this led to successful outcomes? In some ways this seems like a boy’s club where people who are friends just give deals to each other and share their research, and another way to perpetuate biases… (edited)  Jeffrey Bussgang  5:42 PM On the question from @Amna Ali regarding right and wrong with respect

question: Can you describe the most appealing aspects of the Squire business model? Additionally, can you explain why the founders encountered difficulties in raising their seed round?

answer:
The KhataBook case revolves around several key issues. The first is the company's approach to monetization. As of January 2020, KhataBook, a digital ledger app for small businesses in India, had not generated any revenues or determined its ultimate business model, despite having raised $26.7 million through seed funding and a Series A round. The company had focused on customer acquisition and retention, as well as running a series of monetization experiments. Potential monetization opportunities considered by the company included lending as a service, a freemium model, and advertising. 

The second issue is the timing of KhataBook's monetization efforts. The case compares KhataBook's situation to other startups, some of which faced less pressure from investors to monetize. For instance, Codecademy, an online platform offering coding classes, had the support of its investors in strategically delaying monetization experiments.

The third issue is the ethical choices made by KhataBook's co-founder and CEO, Ravish Naresh. The case discusses Naresh's aggressive competition strategies, such as copying a peer's concept, using images without permission in marketing campaigns, and attempting to steal away a competitor's funding.

Lastly, the case also touches on the challenges of operating at the bottom of the pyramid. KhataBook's target customers were small retail shops known as kirana shops, a segment that had seen an increase in digitalization of merchant and financial services due to the explosive growth of internet use in India. However, the question remained whether these customers valued the service enough to have a strong willingness to pay, thus affecting the company's total addressable market.

shortly after OkCredit had just closed an even larger financing: a $67 million Series B round. Intent on raising a Series B funding round, Naresh considered monetization opportunities, including lending as a service, a freemium model, advertising, and others, while also increasing app downloads and post-install usage. But as a small team of only 40 employees, Naresh would need to choose his priorities carefully. Case Positioning This case is used in Launching Technology Ventures (LTV), an elective curriculum course for second-year MBA students at Harvard Business School. LTV was designed for students who plan to start their own companies, join early-stage startups, work at growth-stage technology firms, or invest in startups. This case is part of LTV’s third module, focused on business model experiments. As the module’s final case, it serves as a bridge case to connect to the course’s fourth module focused on financing, exits, and ethics. The case is appropriate for MBA and executive education audiences, as well as undergraduate courses on entrepreneurship or startup business models. Teaching Objectives The KhataBook case is intended to show students:  The importance of product-led growth as a technique to drive customer adoption and some of the design principles inherent in that strategy, including virality and a user experience that drives repeated usage. The criticality of the quality of growth, not just quantity. Adding users that disengage shortly after product trial

Source: "KhataBook Teaching Plan.docx - 4/20"
strategy, including virality and a user experience that drives repeated usage. The criticality of the quality of growth, not just quantity. Adding users that disengage shortly after product trial leads to a “leaky bucket” phenomenon. This case pushes students to look beyond headling-grabbing, “vanity metrics” and understand the underlying usage metrics that drive loyalty and value. Reinforce the concept that startups are experimentation machines and a founder’s choice of experiments is a strategic one. Startup experiments occur within an envelope of time and money and, thus, the sequencing of the experiments—in this case growth then usage then monetization—is critical. As it is set in India, this case also provides students with a vehicle to explore the different rules and playbooks that founders face in developing countries. For example, using capital as a competitive weapon and securing funding from one of the few large capital providers is even more critical than in a developed country where capital and prospective investors are more abundant. Finally, KhataBook describes a founder who pushes the limits of aggressive competition and ethical behavior—copying a peer’s concept, using images without permission in marketing campaigns, trying to steal away a competitor’s funding. Thus, the case provides a platform to discuss the boundaries of ethics in entrepreneurship. Assignment Questions How would you characterize KhataBook’s approach to monetization? Compare KhataBook’s

use the app to take and receive orders with other users. They, in turn, may then begin using KhataBook’s bookkeeping features. Likewise, the overall retention rate could increase, as new users that downloaded the app for the bookkeeping function could stick with the app if it added e-commerce features. Pasture Two: Bottom of the Pyramid (20 minutes) Transition to the second pasture with an assessment of KhataBook’s existing market. Ask: Why is KhataBook a real opportunity in 2019 versus five years ago? Students should refer to Case pp. 2-3, noting that digital adoption lagged among KhataBook’s target customers, kirana shop owners, and other small business owners. However, the explosive growth of internet use in India due to declining smartphone prices and increased online penetration driven by Reliance Jio had seen an increase in digitalization of merchant and financial services.  Follow up, asking students a more provocative question, Can you build a big business at the bottom of the pyramid? Or are KhataBook’s target customers willing to use a free app but do not value the service enough to have a strong willingness to pay (WTP), lifetime value (LTV), and thus total addressable market (TAM)? Teaching Plan—KhataBook 821-007Teaching Plan—KhataBook This teaching plan is designed to be used in conjunction with the case “KhataBook,” HBS No. 821-006 and its related products to help faculty deepen students’ comprehension of business issues and energize classroom discussion and includes these sections: Synopsis	1 Case Positioning	2 Teaching Objectives	2 Assignment Questions	3 Supplemental Readings	3 Roadmap for Discussion	3 Discussion Plan	4 Wrap Up	8 Suggestions for Online Learning	9 Board Plan	10 Synopsis In January 2020, Ravish Naresh, co-founder and CEO of India-based KhataBook, a digital ledger app for small businesses to record financial transactions and accept payments online, is at a crossroads. Operating in a fast-moving, competitive market, KhataBook could focus on customer acquisition, customer retention, or running a series of monetization experiments. Since its launch in 2018, KhataBook had raised $26.7 million through seed funding and a Series A round. By executing on product-led growth techniques, the startup had grown rapidly as measured by downloads and transactions. Yet, it had not generated any revenues or even determined its ultimate business model. After background on the rapid growth of internet accessibility and smartphone usage in India, as well as the digitization of services for merchants and shopkeepers—namely among small retail shops known in India as kirana shops—the case explores Naresh’s early career. Naresh took part in several startups

up a self-generating flywheel. Khatabook can generate a lot of value for creditors by both being able to provide access to underserved mom and pop stores across rural India, and also having the data to filter/identify those most suitable for credit. Capturing a share of the value thus created for creditors opens up a viable monetization opportunity. Would love to hear others’ perspectives. 3 replies Last reply 7 months agoView thread Saurabh Gupta  5:45 PM Hi team, sharing my reflections from today’s discussion and from the coffee chat with Ravish later today. I came to the class thinking that Khatabook has a bleak chance to survive, because of a) low WTP for anything amongst shopkeepers (my Dad is a Kirana shop owner in India!), b) huge competition in lending services as @Raghav Gupta  mentioned and c) lack of high quality data to underwrite risk. However, I was surprised by a few milestones Khatabook has achieved post the case - supported 10M merchants through the pandemic, currently operating at 600K monthly app installs all through the WOM (seriously!!), Ravish’s fundraising ability (raised >175M$ now) for Khatabook. Overall, it looks like a VC money fueled product growth, but the sustainability story is yet to be told. There are still huge risks for the business. Ravish mentioned, during the coffee chat that he’s calibrating his mindset to build a business (he’s built products last 15 years but not business). Khatabook is still building human capital in the org to build

Startup experiments occur within an envelope of time and money and, thus, the sequencing of the experiments—in this case growth then usage then monetization—is critical. As it is set in India, this case also provides students with a vehicle to explore the different rules and playbooks that founders face in developing countries. For example, using capital as a competitive weapon and securing funding from one of the few large capital providers is even more critical than in a developed country where capital and prospective investors are more abundant. Finally, KhataBook describes a founder who pushes the limits of aggressive competition and ethical behavior—copying a peer’s concept, using images without permission in marketing campaigns, trying to steal away a competitor’s funding. Thus, the case provides a platform to discuss the boundaries of ethics in entrepreneurship. Assignment Questions How would you characterize KhataBook’s approach to monetization? Compare KhataBook’s

use the app to take and receive orders with other users. They, in turn, may then begin using KhataBook’s bookkeeping features. Pasture Two: Bottom of the Pyramid (20 minutes) Transition to the second pasture with an assessment of KhataBook’s existing market. Ask: Why is KhataBook a real opportunity in 2019 versus five years ago? Students should refer to Case pp. 2-3, noting that digital adoption lagged among KhataBook’s target customers, kirana shop owners, and other small business owners. However, the explosive growth of internet use in India due to declining smartphone prices and increased online penetration driven by Reliance Jio had seen an increase in digitalization of merchant and financial services.  Follow up, asking students a more provocative question, Can you build a big business at the bottom of the pyramid? Or are KhataBook’s target customers willing to use a free app but do not value the service enough to have a strong willingness to pay (WTP), lifetime value (LTV), and thus total addressable market (TAM)? Teaching Plan—KhataBook 821-007Teaching Plan—KhataBook This teaching plan is designed to be used in conjunction with the case “KhataBook,” HBS No. 821-006 and its related products to help faculty deepen students’ comprehension of business issues and energize classroom discussion and includes these sections: Synopsis	1 Case Positioning	2 Teaching Objectives	2 Assignment Questions	3 Supplemental Readings	3 Roadmap for Discussion	3 Discussion Plan	4 Wrap Up	8 Suggestions for Online Learning	9 Board Plan	10 Synopsis In January 2020, Ravish Naresh, co-founder and CEO of India-based KhataBook, a digital ledger app for small businesses to record financial transactions and accept payments online, is at a crossroads. Operating and functioning are often one and the same thing. Since its launch in 2018, KhataBook had raised $26.7 million through seed funding and a Series A round. By executing on product-led growth techniques, the startup had grown rapidly as measured by downloads and transactions. Yet, it had not generated any revenues or even determined its ultimate business model. After background on the rapid growth of internet accessibility and smartphone usage in India, as well as the digitization of services for merchants and shopkeepers—namely among small retail shops known in India as kirana shops—the case explores Naresh’s early career. Naresh took part in several startups

Source: "LTV 2022 Slack.docx - 74/214"
up a self-generating flywheel. Khatabook can generate a lot of value for creditors by both being able to provide access to underserved mom and pop stores across rural India, and also having the data to filter/identify those most suitable for credit. Capturing a share of the value thus created for creditors opens up a viable monetization opportunity. Would love to hear others’ perspectives. 3 replies Last reply 7 months agoView thread Saurabh Gupta  5:45 PM Hi team, sharing my reflections from today’s discussion and from the coffee chat with Ravish later today. I came to the class thinking that Khatabook has a bleak chance to survive, because of a) low WTP for anything amongst shopkeepers (my Dad is a Kirana shop owner in India!), b) huge competition in lending services as @Raghav Gupta  mentioned and c) lack of high quality data to underwrite risk. However, I was surprised by a few milestones Khatabook has achieved post the case - supported 10M merchants through the pandemic, currently operating at 600K monthly app installs all through the WOM (seriously!!), Ravish’s fundraising ability (raised >175M$ now) for Khatabook. Overall, it looks like a VC money fueled product growth, but the sustainability story is yet to be told. There are still huge risks for the business. Ravish mentioned, during the coffee chat that he’s calibrating his mindset to build a business (he’s built products last 15 years but not business). Khatabook is still building human capital in the org to build

The digital revolution has ushered in an era of unprecedented access to information and has drastically reduced the costs of communication. This has had a profound impact on all aspects of our lives, from how we work to how we socialize and learn. In the world of business, the digital revolution has levelled the playing field, allowing small startups to compete with large established firms. One of the key factors in this transformation has been the advent of digital marketing, which has given businesses of all sizes the ability to reach a global audience at a fraction of the cost of traditional marketing methods. The growth of social media has further amplified this impact, providing a platform for businesses to engage with their customers in a more personal and direct manner.

question: Could you provide a summary of the key issues in the Khatabook case? Please answer the assignment questions to the best of your ability, making educated guesses where necessary, and provide as much detail as possible.

answer: The key decision point for the founders of Bubble is whether to accept outside funding to scale their business more quickly. This decision would allow them to change their hiring model, expand their team, and establish themselves as a major player in the emerging market of low-code and no-code software. However, accepting outside funding would also present a number of additional questions, such as how they would use the capital and how their hiring process would evolve.
context:
Source: "On the Bubble - Startup Bootstrapping.pdf - Page 7"
On the Bubble: Startup Bootstrapping  822-033  7 the founders then did a so -called life interview, asking a potential hire to summarize their life and  justify the decisions they made along the way. Other interview topics included a case study of a typical  full-stacka web application (such as Facebook’s News Feed feature), asking applicants how they would  design and build such a program.  From this process, t he founders hired two new employees, both of  whom were recent college graduates  and junior software engineers . The starting salary was around  $80,000, in line with the expected salary for coders at that level.   After expanding their engineering  capacity, the founders decided it was time to hire employees to  help with other aspects of the business. In July 2017, Haas and Straschnov  hired Bubble’s first employee  focused on customer success.  In November 2017, realizing that they needed someone to handle  financials and track metrics while the founders and other employees were focused on the product and  customers, they  hired a director of operations . The hires were based on the idea that  Bubble should  focus on improving and increasing capacity on the foundation the founders had already built , rather  than expand into new areas . “It’s a lot easier to hire for a job you’re alre ady doing than to hire for a job

Source: "On the Bubble - Startup Bootstrapping.pdf - Page 1"
fervent fan base  of fellow startup founders who would have otherwise needed a technical cofounder  or an engineering team to release software products.  However , the Bubble founders had  bigger ambitions. They wanted to build a product that would  allow  anyone, including those without any technical skills,  to build  software  products for profit or  personal fulfillment . By 2018, the notion of low -code and no -code sof tware was gaining momentum ,  and competing products existed, though the  market was niche and mostly unknown  in 2012, when  Bubble launched . While Haas and Straschnov were proud of their measured approach to date , they  knew an injection of cash would allow them to change their hiring model, scale more quickly , and  establish themselves as a major player in the emerging market.   Accepting outside funding would present a number of additional questions. I f they raised capital,  what would they actually do with it? W ith only a handful of employees, the company had pressing  needs in nearly every functional area: engineering, marketing, sales.
