Source: "On the Bubble - Startup Bootstrapping.pdf - Page 5"
On the Bubble: Startup Bootstrapping  822-033  5 that the product had enough functionality to ju stify charging users for premium features. Thus, they  created a premium product that allowed users to personalize their creation and launch their business.  By that point, customers were typically more  amenable to counting Bubble ’s price as an operating  expense.  Customers were “locked in” to the Bubble platform ; if they stopped paying, they would lose  access to the products they had coded on Bubble .  Walkthroughs Bubble’s many automated tutorials and walkthroughs  allowed users to learn  the  prod uct’s capabilities quickly, without needing contact with anyone at Bubble.  Teaching people to use  Bubble was crucial  to spreading awareness of it s existence  to potential customers. More people using  Bubble to build applications and websites meant more peop le interacting with Bubble -designed  projects, and more companies founded as Bubble clients.  “The old adage, about if someone has a  hammer, then everything they see is a nail —we’re trying to teach more people how to use the Bubble  hammer, so that they see more nails out there that they can use Bubble for,” Haas said. “Anyone  learning Bubble we regard as a win for us, and that’s the primary driver of user acquisition.”   Discussion Forum As Bubble’s popularity grew , Straschnov struggled to respond to a growing  influx of customer emails while still attending to his other responsibilities. The founders’ solution was

Source: "LTV 2022 - All Case Takeaways.pdf - Page 154"
Bubble: The Issues •Bootstrapping: benefits and downsides •Timing to raise capital •Hiring your first team members

Source: "On the Bubble - Startup Bootstrapping.pdf - Page 6"
soured our attitudes and stopped us from raising funds for at least a period of time, just because of the  level of disconnect.” The founders also realized that VC  firms had metrics for success that did not  necessarily align with their  own . “One of the big sticking points was around timelines,” Haas said.  “They wanted us to grow, grow, grow, grow, grow, and we wanted to do product development, product development, p roduct development.”  The founders decided to continue bootstrapping the  business and running expenses at essentially breakeven.   Hiring  the Team   As Bubble’s revenue grew, the founders felt they finally had the capacity to slowly build  out their  team. In October 2015, over three years after starting the company, the  founders  hired their first  employee to help with  coding . The hire was unplanned, and  they did not write a job description or  solicit applications. Instead, a project manager with engineering exper ience who was a fan of Bubble’s   mission reached out to ask about a job. “ Bringing a third person into the company was not quite  bringing on a third cofounder, but it was more than bringing on a simple employee,” Straschnov said. They paid him $50,000, well  below the prevailing wage for engineers  at the time. While hiring  gave the  cofounders a sense of  progress, the employee  was not a good  cultural  fit, and they parted ways in May

If the founders decided to raise the capital, they were unsure how to spend it. Like many o ther  bootstrapped founders, they could choose to take some or most of the money off the table by selling  their own shares. Or s hould they continue their investment in the product and customer success,  following the PLG path even further  to build a larger m ore valuable company at a faster rate ? Or was  it time to invest in building out a sales and marketing team, much as Atlassian, Dropbox, Slack, and Zoom did as they scaled? Further, how should their hiring process evolve as they went from hiring one or two incremental team members to more than doubling or even tripling the size of the company?

Or s hould they continue their investment in the product and customer success,  following the PLG path even further  to build a larger m ore valuable company at a faster rate ? Or was  it time to invest in building out a sales and marketing team, much as Atlassian, Dropbox, Slack, and Zoom did as they scaled? Further, how should their hiring process evolve as they went from hiring one or two incremental team members to more than doubling or even tripling the size of the company?

question: What is the key decision point for the founders of Bubble?

answer:
When determining if a startup is an appropriate early-stage investment opportunity, you should consider the following factors: 

1. Team: Assess the founding team's ability to articulate a compelling vision, their integrity, and whether they inspire you and others around them. 

2. Market: Evaluate if the market the company is operating in is massive (i.e., greater than $1 billion in revenue potential), experiencing disruption that might lead to opportunity for a new entrant like this startup, and how crowded the market is. 

3. Business Model: Check if the unit economics are attractive, if the company can articulate the lifetime value of each customer, the acquisition cost of each customer, and compare the two. 

4. Stage of the Startup: Understand the operational maturity, cash position, and path to growth for the company. The stage of a startup will reflect the skills needed for hires as well. 

5. Resilience and Attitude: Look for resilience and a can-do attitude in the team. 

6. Risk: Be aware that early-stage startups are more likely to fail or go sideways, and you may be looking for another job in a year or two. 

7. Experimentation: Consider if the startup is willing to experiment and test their business model components, especially the most controversial ones. 

8. Long-term Value Creation: Early-stage startups are typically technology-driven with deep Intellectual Property (IP). If the technology works, value is created. The holding period for early-stage startups is typically 6-8 years, so an episodic recession shouldn't materially affect long-term value creation, so long as follow-on financing is available.

Source: "https://seeingbothsides.com/2008/09/21/vc-take-on-market-crash-short-term-bear-long-term-bull/"
But it's better to be down 30% than 300%.  In truth, most early-stage companies are not that affected by the stock market gyrations or even a general recession.  Yes, some consumer-based "if you build it, they will come" businesses will be more susceptible to the inevitable pullback in advertising spend.  But most venture-backed start-ups are technology-driven with deep Intellectual Property (IP).  If the technology works, value is created.  With only a few customer proof points, a few million of revenue can be generated from scratch and even more value can be created.  The holding period for early-stage start-ups is typically 6-8 years, and so an episodic recession shouldn't materially affect long-term value creation, so long as follow-on financing is available.  One VC observed that his partnership had done an analysis and realized that, "we have 20 companies in our portfolio seeking follow-on financing this year.  They'll nearly all get done, but none of them will be meaningfully up rounds.  Instead, there will be many flat and down rounds ahead".
Source: "https://bothsidesofthetable.com/on-funding-shots-on-goal-ad2eb69e8ba3"
Being great as a startup technology investor of course requires a lot of things to come together: I’ve definitely been wrong on market value. I’ve sometimes been right about the market value but too early. And I’ve been spot on with both but backed the 2nd, 3rd or 4th best player in a market. In short: Access to great deals, ability to be invited to invest in these deals, ability to see where value in a market will be created and the luck to back the right team with the right market at the right time all matter. When you first start your career as an investor (or when you first start writing angel checks) your main obsession is “getting into great deals.” You’re thinking about one bullet at a time. When you’ve been playing the game a bit longer or when you have responsibilities at the fund level you start thinking more about “portfolio construction.” At Upfront we often talk about these as “shots on goal” (a fitting soccer analogy given the EURO 2020 tournament is on right now). What we discuss internally and what I discuss with my LPs is outlined as follows: We tell our LPs the truth, which is that when we write the first check we think each one is going to be an amazing company but 10–15 years later it has been much hard to have predicted which would be the major fund drivers. Consider: Almost every successful company is a mixture of very hard work by the founders mixed with a pinch of luck, good fortune and perseverance.

Source: "https://feld.com/archives/2008/02/why-am-i-passing/"
Assume something falls in the "yes – this is interesting / relevant to my current investment themes and yes – I’m at least interested in the people."  Before I spent a lot my time (and their time) I try to figure out where this lives in the context of all the other companies we are looking at investing in. This is where it gets fuzzy for the entrepreneur.  You don’t know the other active companies that we are working on.  We do.  Since all of my partners and I work across all of our deals, we all have good knowledge of the depth of our current pipeline.  As a result, I can ask myself the question "is this deal potentially in the top five things we are currently looking at." If not, I usually pass right away.  We’ll only make a half dozen new investments or so a year and we are always looking at many more than six companies that we think are potentially fantastic investments.  As a result, if something is merely good (or even great) in our mind, it’s not going to ultimately make the cut, so it doesn’t make sense to spend time on it. This is one of the benefit of having a fund our size.  While we aren’t a slave to a specific annual deal pacing, we’ve learned through the lessons of the bubble the value of having time diversity in our investing activity.  To be hugely successful, we don’t have to do every great deal we see.  In fact, we don’t have to do every fantastic deal we see.

204 E ntering StartUpLand Chapter_08.indd  Page 204  26/07/17  10:38 PM industry you’re looking at. If you already know some people in that  industry, reach out to them to ask these questions. This process will help you narrow down a potentially paralyzing sea of options  to a much smaller starting point. If you don’t already know people  in that industry, the next section—on positioning yourself—can help you find some. As discussed, picking a winner is hard for professional inves - tors like me. Thus, do not expect to pick the next Facebook or Google on every try. You will want to blend your best survey of conventional wisdom with your own judgment and instincts. Even if you are wrong (worst case, if the company you join fails),  you can point to a thoughtful methodology when the next inter - viewer asks you “Why did you join that company and what did  you learn from it?” Note, too, that there is often a trade-off to consider when you’re  trying to select a winner. An earlier-stage company, particularly one that is not necessarily perceived as “hot” and has a huge amount of momentum, will be more willing to take a risk on you and give you more responsibility than a more mature growth stage com - pany. At the earlier stages, you will have the opportunity to play  multiple roles, grow more rapidly, and have more senior exposure.
Source: "Entering Startup Land.pdf - Page 213"
multiple roles, grow more rapidly, and have more senior exposure.  The downside is that you are less likely to have great mentors from whom you can learn as compared to a larger startup. Further, it is more likely that this early-stage startup will fail or go sideways and you will be looking for another job in a year or two. If you are  willing to take more risk and operate with greater uncertainty, the  quality of the experience at the early-stage startup can be superior to that of being a small cog in the larger, hot startup. This series of steps—picking your domain, your city, the stage  you’re most interested in, and companies within that city that fit  that stage in that sector—generally results in a very small list.  Thus, at that point, you can decide which companies to focus on. If you’re in a larger startup community—like San Francisco, New York, or Boston—you tend to have a lot of companies that are in  the particular stage and sector. Assume something falls in the "yes – this is interesting / relevant to my current investment themes and yes – I’m at least interested in the people."  Before I spent a lot my time (and their time) I try to figure out where this lives in the context of all the other companies we are looking at investing in. This is where it gets fuzzy for the entrepreneur.  You don’t know the other active companies that we are working on.  We do.  Since all of my partners and I work across all of our deals, we all have good knowledge of the depth of our current pipeline.  As a result, I can ask myself the question "is this deal potentially in the top five things we are currently looking at." If not, I usually pass right away.  We’ll only make a half dozen new investments or so a year and we are always looking at many more than six companies that we think are potentially fantastic investments.  As a result, if something is merely good (or even great) in our mind, it’s not going to ultimately make the cut, so it doesn’t make sense to spend time on it. This is one of the benefit of having a fund our size.  While we aren’t a slave to a specific annual deal pacing, we’ve learned through the lessons of the bubble the value of having time diversity in our investing activity.  To be hugely successful, we don’t have to do every great deal we see.  In fact, we don’t have to do every fantastic deal we see.

Source: "https://bothsidesofthetable.com/on-funding-shots-on-goal-ad2eb69e8ba3"
Being great as a startup technology investor of course requires a lot of things to come together: I’ve definitely been wrong on market value. I’ve sometimes been right about the market value but too early. And I’ve been spot on with both but backed the 2nd, 3rd or 4th best player in a market. In short: Access to great deals, ability to be invited to invest in these deals, ability to see where value in a market will be created and the luck to back the right team with the right market at the right time all matter. When you first start your career as an investor (or when you first start writing angel checks) your main obsession is “getting into great deals.” You’re thinking about one bullet at a time. When you’ve been playing the game a bit longer or when you have responsibilities at the fund level you start thinking more about “portfolio construction.” At Upfront we often talk about these as “shots on goal” (a fitting soccer analogy given the EURO 2020 tournament is on right now). What we discuss internally and what I discuss with my LPs is outlined as follows: We tell our LPs the truth, which is that when we write the first check we think each one is going to be an amazing company but 10–15 years later it has been much hard to have predicted which would be the major fund drivers. Consider: Almost every successful company is a mixture of very hard work by the founders mixed with a pinch of luck, good fortune and perseverance.

204 E ntering StartUpLand Chapter_08.indd  Page 204  26/07/17  10:38 PM industry you’re looking at. If you already know some people in that  industry, reach out to them to ask these questions. This process will help you narrow down a potentially paralyzing sea of options  to a much smaller starting point. If you don’t already know people  in that industry, the next section—on positioning yourself—can help you find some. As discussed, picking a winner is hard for professional inves - tors like me. Thus, do not expect to pick the next Facebook or Google on every try. You will want to blend your best survey of conventional wisdom with your own judgment and instincts. Even if you are wrong (worst case, if the company you join fails),  you can point to a thoughtful methodology when the next inter - viewer asks you “Why did you join that company and what did  you learn from it?” Note, too, that there is often a trade-off to consider when you’re  trying to select a winner. An earlier-stage company, particularly one that is not necessarily perceived as “hot” and has a huge amount of momentum, will be more willing to take a risk on you and give you more responsibility than a more mature growth stage com - pany. At the earlier stages, you will have the opportunity to play  multiple roles, grow more rapidly, and have more senior exposure.

How does an outsider conduct due diligence like an insider? Use the rubric that all investors use. Evaluate each company along the same criteria we venture capitalists employ,  which are typically three simple ones. And think long and hard as I tell my students. But it's better to be down 30% than 300%.  In truth, most early-stage companies are not that affected by the stock market gyrations or even a general recession.  Yes, some consumer-based "if you build it, they will come" businesses will be more susceptible to the inevitable pullback in advertising spend.  But most venture-backed start-ups are technology-driven with deep Intellectual Property (IP).  If the technology works, value is created.  With only a few customer proof points, a few million of revenue can be generated from scratch and even more value can be created.  The holding period for early-stage start-ups is typically 6-8 years, and so an episodic recession shouldn't materially affect long-term value creation, so long as follow-on financing is available.  One VC observed that his partnership had done an analysis and realized that, "we have 20 companies in our portfolio seeking follow-on financing this year.  They'll nearly all get done, but none of them will be meaningfully up rounds.  Instead, there will be many flat and down rounds ahead".

Students also often choose convenience samples — e.g., of classmates/friends who aren’t in their target customer group — that yield biased results. Don’t  make these mistakes!     • Analysis of rivals’ features*: The book Observing the User Experience  includes a chapter on competitor research. Your task would be to  analyze  the feature sets for rivals to a startup, and make recommendations on  whether the startup should change or adapt its product in response to  findings.     • Usability test*: To run a usability test, all you need is an app/website, a  target task to complete, and a test subject or two. Tom Eisenmann’s Product  Design resource list includes a section on usability testing; the books  Observing the User Experience and UX for Lean Startups discuss usability  testing at length; and we particularly recommend Steve Krug's book Rocket  Surgery Made Easy , which is a short, practical, and funny guide to the basics  of usability research. You could recruit fellow HBS’ers if they are  representative of target users — for example, you mi ght ask RC students to  try completing some tasks on Canvas. After the successful execution of the previous business plans, the team was brimming with optimism for their future plans. The feedback they had received from their clients had strengthened their belief in the product they were building. Furthermore, the exponential growth in their user base was a testament to the potential the product had in the market. They had successfully identified a gap in the market and their product was meeting the demands of that gap effectively. The journey had been challenging, but the results were gratifying. The company was not just financially successful but also influential in shaping industry trends.The digital revolution has ushered in an era of unprecedented access to information and has drastically reduced the costs of communication. This has had a profound impact on all aspects of our lives, from how we work to how we socialize and learn. In the world of business, the digital revolution has levelled the playing field, allowing small startups to compete with large established firms. One of the key factors in this transformation has been the advent of digital marketing, which has given businesses of all sizes the ability to reach a global audience at a fraction of the cost of traditional marketing methods. The growth of social media has further amplified this impact, providing a platform for businesses to engage with their customers in a more personal and direct manner."The Entrepreneurial Manager” as well as Field 2, but particularly the following Case Notes: Ten Tools for Design Thinking (UV5187)  The Hypothesis-Driven Entrepreneurship: The Lean Start-Up (812-095)  Business Model Analysis for Entrepreneurs (812-096)  Customer Discovery and Validation for Entrepreneurs (812-097)  For students who want an accessible primer on software development processes and coding, read: Paul Ford | What is Code? Wallace has a BA in psychology and economics from Amherst College, an MPA in public leadership and social entrepreneurship from Harvard Kennedy School, and an MBA from Harvard Business School . used DNA sequencing technology to determine the risk that parents would pass genetic disorders to  future children. Wallace explained, “I was the fertility entrepreneur in Boston. I saw most of the  women ’s health startups in Boston because I had built a successful one. ” As it happened, Wallace was  transitioning out of Good Start and looking for new opportunities in health technology, and Ovuline seemed like a good fit. Wallace agreed to come onboard as CEO as Tofan transitioned out. Wallace then recruited Rory O ’Connor, a friend and fellow Amherst College alumnus, as vice president of  engineering. Wallace and O ’Connor both began working full -time with the company. Wallace  explained, “ It was risky, but I had b uilt a company before and I knew that Ovuline was a good idea, so  I felt confident in the decision to work on it full -time. ” The team prepared to launch an updated fertility  app and raise an initial seed financing  round  using HBS ’s i-Lab as a workspace.   Since 2011, Wallace had been a mentor for Techstars, which ran 90 -day startup accelerators in  various cities around the world. A few weeks ago, my friend Alan Shimel connected me with Jennifer Leggio.  Jennifer is the Director of Strategic Communications at Fortinet and an active blogger in – among other things – security and communication.  Alan suggested to Jennifer that she might be interested in the work we have been doing at the National Center for Women & Information Technology. I remember the conversation fondly because I was sitting on the floor upstairs at Oblong’s office in LA while a bunch of people ran around downstairs looking at some cool stuff that Oblong was presenting to one of their customers.  Oblong had recently moved in to their new office and there was a noticeable lack of comfortable surfaces or devices to sit on (or in) upstairs.  The floor had to make do.  It was actually pretty clean and comfortable. Jennifer asked a bunch of hard questions.  We had a great conversation.  I connected her with Lucy Sanders, the CEO of NCWIT, and they talked.  Jennifer got her mind around how to engage in the problem NCWIT is addressing and Women in IT – Be A Change Agent (Part One) is the post she wrote kicking off her thoughts and actions. I appear to have said at least one memorable thing during our conversation:

Source: "https://feld.com/archives/2011/08/jessica-schallock-artist/"
[Jessica Schallock – Artist]  Amy and I collect contemporary art. We often make friends with the artists who we collect. Occasionally people who are our friends become artists. Jessica Schallock fits into this category We’ve been friends with Jessica for a decade. Her family lives next door to us in Homer, Alaska and we’ve known Jessica since she was 12. We’ve watched, with much joy, as she’s grown into an amazingly talented young women. One of those talents is art. Every year she gives us a drawing as a gift. It’s been amazingly fun to watch her get better at drawing, as she turns it from a childhood hobby to a profession. She’s currently experimenting with of realistic portions of a face that blend into “unfinished” sketch-like outlines. The piece in this post is called James and is 16 1/2″ x 20″, graphite on Bristol board. Jessica is looking for a gallery to work with along with people that are interested in her work. If you are interested, please email me and I’ll put y’all in touch.

Source: "https://feld.com/archives/2016/11/givingthanks-lucy-sanders-ncwit/"
Next up in my #GivingThanks series – in appreciation for people during Thanksgiving who have had a profound impact on me – is Lucy Sanders, the CEO of the National Center for Women & Information Technology (NCWIT). Unlike the last post about the Jason Mendelson Entrepreneurial Award Fund, I’m not going to bury the lede – go here if you’d like to make a financial gift to NCWIT as part of #GivingThanks. I met Lucy in 2004. We were introduced by Terry Gold (I was on the board at Gold Systems). Terry has always been a great connector so without knowing anything about Lucy I said “sure” and we had a meeting in my old office in Superior above a liquor store and Old Chicago Pizza. In the first few minutes, Lucy explained her plans for a new organization she had created called National Center for Women & Information Technology. Her goal was straightforward – get more girls and women involved in computer science. As someone who has been involved in the tech industry since 1987, there was an obvious gender issue – all you needed to do was walk around a software company and look at the engineers. But Lucy captured my attention when she went further than the issue of gender parity by saying in the first five minutes something like “It’s an issue of long term competitiveness and innovation. In the US, the demand for computer scientists and programmers is growing at a pace that will dramatically outstrip the supply of labor unless we get more women involved, starting now.”

For a while, the only name on the list was Lindel’s. It took us several years to get our mind around adding someone, but once we did, we added a few more names to the list. It probably won’t be a surprise to anyone reading this that it is a very short list. Back to Chris Moody. Chris was most recently VP & GM of Data & Solutions at Twitter, running a multi-hundred million dollar enterprise business unit. In addition to running one of Twitter’s fastest-growing business unit, Chris was responsible for leading Twitter’s developer platform and ecosystem involving hundreds of enterprise partners and one of the world’s largest active developer communities. We’ve known Chris since 2007 and worked extremely closely with him when he was the CEO of Gnip and well as a leader in the Boulder Startup Community. Over the years, we also became very close friends with Chris. After we had raised the first Foundry Group Next fund last September, we started having a serious conversation about having Chris join us at Foundry Group. This was driven by our reflection on our current workload, how we were adjusting what we were doing based on the addition of Lindel to the team – which had re-energized us a lot, and how we were thinking about the next ten years of Foundry Group.

Having 50% of the market with the price that we'd have to give that channel partner wasn't attractive and would hinder our ability to raise money. [00:34:39.77] And then secondly, I think, from a mission alignment standpoint, that channel partner wanted to stop doing some of the things we were doing for users that were really valuable, and that was something that we were never going to do. So we raised a Series A to build out a direct sales force. And they went out and sold directly through some other channel partners as well as through their own contacts as we built the business out. A R C H I E  L .  J O N E S   J E F F R E Y  J .  B U S S G A N G   H E N R Y  W .  M C G E E   Clara Wu Tsai and Brooklyn Loan Innovation   Clara didn’t just come in and say, “I know  the answers.” She said, “We want to do something but let me talk  to people who have been invested in these communities, who really know the challenges and let me learn.”   — Gregg Bishop, Social Justice Fund Executive Director1  As the buzzer  signal ed the end  of the game on the evening of June 17, 2021 in the Fiserv Forum  arena in Milwaukee, Wisconsin, the emotions and thoughts of Clara Wu Tsai  (MBA ’93) , owner of  National Basketball Association (NBA) team Brooklyn Nets, ranged widely. She had two “MVPs ” to  worry about.  One was the opposing team’s most valuable player, who stood between her basketball  team ’s and Brooklyn’s first NBA Championship. Equally troubling was the minimum viable product  that she was trying to rapidly deploy to impact economic empowerment in Brooklyn and beyond.   Just over a year ago, George Floyd, a Black man, was murdered in Minneapolis when a White police  officer knelt on Floyd’s neck for nine and a half minutes. The video of the tragedy and the ensuing  community activism igni ted a global discussion on racial justice and equity . It also inspired Wu Tsai to  act in her own backyard and focus locally on social justice and economic mobility in Brooklyn’s Black

M C G E E   Clara Wu Tsai and Brooklyn Loan Innovation   Clara didn’t just come in and say, “I know  the answers.” She said, “We want to do something but let me talk  to people who have been invested in these communities, who really know the challenges and let me learn.”   — Gregg Bishop, Social Justice Fund Executive Director1  As the buzzer  signal ed the end  of the game on the evening of June 17, 2021 in the Fiserv Forum  arena in Milwaukee, Wisconsin, the emotions and thoughts of Clara Wu Tsai  (MBA ’93) , owner of  National Basketball Association (NBA) team Brooklyn Nets, ranged widely. She had two “MVPs ” to  worry about.  One was the opposing team’s most valuable player, who stood between her basketball  team ’s and Brooklyn’s first NBA Championship. Equally troubling was the minimum viable product  that she was trying to rapidly deploy to impact economic empowerment in Brooklyn and beyond.   Just over a year ago, George Floyd, a Black man, was murdered in Minneapolis when a White police  officer knelt on Floyd’s neck for nine and a half minutes. The video of the tragedy and the ensuing  community activism igni ted a global discussion on racial justice and equity . It also inspired Wu Tsai to  act in her own backyard and focus locally on social justice and economic mobility in Brooklyn’s Black

A few weeks ago, my friend Alan Shimel connected me with Jennifer Leggio.  Jennifer is the Director of Strategic Communications at Fortinet and an active blogger in – among other things – security and communication.  Alan suggested to Jennifer that she might be interested in the work we have been doing at the National Center for Women & Information Technology. I remember the conversation fondly because I was sitting on the floor upstairs at Oblong’s office in LA while a bunch of people ran around downstairs looking at some cool stuff that Oblong was presenting to one of their customers.  Oblong had recently moved in to their new office and there was a noticeable lack of comfortable surfaces or devices to sit on (or in) upstairs.  The floor had to make do.  It was actually pretty clean and comfortable. Jennifer asked a bunch of hard questions.  We had a great conversation.  I connected her with Lucy Sanders, the CEO of NCWIT, and they talked.  Jennifer got her mind around how to engage in the problem NCWIT is addressing and Women in IT – Be A Change Agent (Part One) is the post she wrote kicking off her thoughts and actions. I appear to have said at least one memorable thing during our conversation:

Source: "https://feld.com/archives/2016/11/givingthanks-lucy-sanders-ncwit/"
Next up in my #GivingThanks series – in appreciation for people during Thanksgiving who have had a profound impact on me – is Lucy Sanders, the CEO of the National Center for Women & Information Technology (NCWIT). Unlike the last post about the Jason Mendelson Entrepreneurial Award Fund, I’m not going to bury the lede – go here if you’d like to make a financial gift to NCWIT as part of #GivingThanks. I met Lucy in 2004. We were introduced by Terry Gold (I was on the board at Gold Systems). Terry has always been a great connector so without knowing anything about Lucy I said “sure” and we had a meeting in my old office in Superior above a liquor store and Old Chicago Pizza. In the first few minutes, Lucy explained her plans for a new organization she had created called National Center for Women & Information Technology. Her goal was straightforward – get more girls and women involved in computer science. As someone who has been involved in the tech industry since 1987, there was an obvious gender issue – all you needed to do was walk around a software company and look at the engineers. But Lucy captured my attention when she went further than the issue of gender parity by saying in the first five minutes something like “It’s an issue of long term competitiveness and innovation. In the US, the demand for computer scientists and programmers is growing at a pace that will dramatically outstrip the supply of labor unless we get more women involved, starting now.”

Source: "https://feld.com/archives/2011/08/jessica-schallock-artist/"
[Jessica Schallock – Artist]  Amy and I collect contemporary art. We often make friends with the artists who we collect. Occasionally people who are our friends become artists. Jessica Schallock fits into this category We’ve been friends with Jessica for a decade. Her family lives next door to us in Homer, Alaska and we’ve known Jessica since she was 12. We’ve watched, with much joy, as she’s grown into an amazingly talented young women. One of those talents is art. Every year she gives us a drawing as a gift. It’s been amazingly fun to watch her get better at drawing, as she turns it from a childhood hobby to a profession. She’s currently experimenting with of realistic portions of a face that blend into “unfinished” sketch-like outlines. The piece in this post is called James and is 16 1/2″ x 20″, graphite on Bristol board. Jessica is looking for a gallery to work with along with people that are interested in her work. If you are interested, please email me and I’ll put y’all in touch.

For a while, the only name on the list was Lindel’s. It took us several years to get our mind around adding someone, but once we did, we added a few more names to the list. It probably won’t be a surprise to anyone reading this that it is a very short list. Back to Chris Moody. Chris was most recently VP & GM of Data & Solutions at Twitter, running a multi-hundred million dollar enterprise business unit. In addition to running one of Twitter’s fastest-growing business unit, Chris was responsible for leading Twitter’s developer platform and ecosystem involving hundreds of enterprise partners and one of the world’s largest active developer communities. We’ve known Chris since 2007 and worked extremely closely with him when he was the CEO of Gnip and well as a leader in the Boulder Startup Community. Over the years, we also became very close friends with Chris. After we had raised the first Foundry Group Next fund last September, we started having a serious conversation about having Chris join us at Foundry Group. This was driven by our reflection on our current workload, how we were adjusting what we were doing based on the addition of Lindel to the team – which had re-energized us a lot, and how we were thinking about the next ten years of Foundry Group.

answer: The founder-market fit of the team at Shippo is a subject of debate. On one hand, neither Behrens Wu nor Kreuz has formal training in software development, which could be seen as a disadvantage given that Shippo's product and customer base are technical in nature. They have struggled to create efficient software development processes and lack general business experience. Behrens Wu's internship experience in customer acquisition may have prepared her for a business-to-consumer (B2C) environment, but not necessarily for a B2B firm that sells to developers. On the other hand, Behrens Wu has demonstrated a commitment to enterprise users and gained a deep appreciation for the power of API technology while building her e-commerce business, Popout, Inc. She also has an authentic interest in the shipping industry due to her international background. The founding team has displayed persistence, grit, and savvy to seek and act on the advice of technology insiders. Kreuz has demonstrated that he can learn the requisite skills to be a developer by building Shippo’s two software products. In addition, Shippo has some business experience: Kreuz has an MBA and Behrens Wu studied in a graduate business program.

such as Quora and Stack Exchange, and can design marketing materials to make them developer-friendly (case p. 9).  In terms of product strategy, Shippo should amplify the value proposition of the API so that they are competing in areas beyond price, for example, by adding additional services like package tracking or insurance.  To spearhead this transformation to a developer-oriented strategy, Shippo might consider hiring an experienced computer scientist for an executive role such as chief of API or even chief technology officer. In that scenario, Kreuz might move into another role such as chief of product.  Wrap Up The instructor may want to wrap up the case discussion with the following closing insights: Founder-market fit can be subtle. While Behrens Wu may have lacked provable technical skills, she had the grit, courage, strategic skills, charisma, and persistence that start-up founders need to be successful in a highly competitive funding environment. Some call this the X factor; others refer to “force of nature” entrepreneurs. Whatever you call it, great founders don’t just have relevant experience and history but can also simply have huge amounts of hustle and other skills to achieve founder-market fit. Rapid customer growth can appear to indicate product-market fit, but may actually represent a false positive. In the case of Shippo, the team offered a strong value proposition and had a good delivery platform (channel), but as churn data shows, the initial product

Behrens Wu has an authentic interest in and stake in the shipping industry because it allows people who live in different places to access the same products (case p. 4). “X Factor.” If they do not have founder-market fit on paper, Shippo’s leaders have something special, often referred to as an “X factor” by investors. The founding team has displayed persistence, grit, and savvy to seek and act on the advice of technology insiders. The team at Plug and Play recognized these qualities when they saw an “enprepreneurial sparkle” in the founders’ eyes (case p. 7). When she had no contacts in the technology start-up world, Behrens Wu networked her way from Germany to an internship in San Francisco (case p. 3). By building Shippo’s two software products, Kreuz has demonstrated that he can learn the requisite skills to be a developer (case p. 4). While Y Combinator is a powerful voice with a strong track record in Silicon Valley, not all VCs are as biased toward technical founders. In addition, Shippo has some business experience: Kreuz has an MBA and Behrens Wu studied in a graduate business program (case pp. 3-4).  Some students may question the concept of founder-market fit, arguing that founders can evolve alongside their companies and should not be limited to industries with which they are familiar. definition. Responses can be recorded on Board 1. No. Shippo lacks founder-market fit because neither Behrens Wu nor Kreuz has formal training in software development. They have already struggled to create efficient software development processes, as exemplified by Figure 2 (case p. 7). They also lack general business experience. Behrens Wu’s internship experience in customer acquisition perhaps prepared her modestly for a business-to-consumer (B2C) environment, not a B2B firm that sells to developers.  The founders’ brief experience as an e-commerce retailer (and Shopify client) makes them sympathetic to the needs of small business owners but does not prepare them to recruit developers. This non-technical team will struggle to attract developers through inbound marketing. The team’s Y Combinator rejection suggests that technology investors are often biased towards entrepreneurs who have a technical background themselves, particularly when the product and customer are technical in nature, as is the case with Shippo.  Yes. Behrens Wu has demonstrated a commitment to enterprise users. She gained a deep appreciation for the power of API technology, specifically payment API Stripe, while building her e-commerce business Popout, Inc. (case p. 4). As someone who has lived in many countries, Behrens Wu has an authentic interest in and stake in the shipping industry because it allows people who live in different places to access the same products (case p. 4). “X Factor.” If they do

an MVP to test and establish product-market fit, entrepreneurs postpone the costs and time associated with fixing the product’s bugs. This technical debt must be repaid in the future to align the product’s quality with customer expectations.  Finally, the instructor may want to conclude the class with a quick update on Shippo’s developments since November 2014. Following the $2 million seed round, Shippo went on to raise $7 million in series A round led by Union Square Ventures (USV). Following the round, USV’s Albert Wenger joined the Shippo board of directors. By September 2016, 10,000 companies together shipped millions of packages using Shippo’s software each month. In addition, Shippo hired engineer Sin-Mei Tsai to serve as vice president of engineering and e-commerce marketer Mikhail Ledvich as head of marketing. In September 2016, Shippo had 28 employees, and offered both a dashboard app and an API, but had decided to focus more tightly on the API strategy as its main growth engine. In a 2016 blogpost, Behrens Wu reflected on the future of her company: “Raising this round is really about growing the company. We will be using the money to hire the right team of people with the skills and experience to move us through a period of rapid growth and scaling.”  Board Plan and Exhibits Board 1 Board 2 Board 2 (continued) App Customer    App Customer                    API Customer    API Customer 40              labels per month                1,300           labels per

Shopify. If a student volunteers to share his or her experiences, ask the student to describe order fulfillment at that company, including which shipping providers were used and why. If the student used the Shopify platform after September 2015, they may have opted to use Shopify’s internal shipping functionality to fulfill orders instead of an app like Shippo.  Invite students with programming experience to discuss the implications of the API-focused strategy and the architecture Shippo has chosen (case Figure 2). By not initially designing the dashboard on top of their own API, Shippo has some built-in limitations. Behrens Wu explains on page 7: “When we added a new API functionality, we had to add a user interface element to the app to allow the user to interact with it.” Use the figure, the quote and the experience of a few students who have been software developers to explain the difficulties in scaling the API and the app in parallel and the importance of focusing on one or the other—along with the potential for a re-architecture in the future to pay down the technical debt from the initial MVP. Note that this discussion will lay some important groundwork for the “What Next?” pasture. Product Metrics Now that students have described the basic business model and concept, ask them to analyze Shippo’s customer traction so far (refer students to case Exhibit 7). While API users made up roughly 1% of the user base, they  generated 36% of revenue  and shipping volume . (See Exhibit 7 for shipping volume  and Exhibit s 8  and 9 for churn and retention data .) Shippo had seven  employees : the two founders ; two employees  handling marketing, customer service, and business development ; and three software engineers . With  Shippo’s  monthly burn rate in mind, Behrens Wu figured she had about nine months of cash runway   left, assuming she did not ramp up staffing fu rther.   Shippo was developing two very different customer personas , and the team worried they did not  have the resources to cater to both.  The smal l businesses had been the backbone of Shippo’s growth.  Traction with that customer base had convinced investors to participate in the seed round , and Behrens  Wu knew  that raising the next round of funding, a Series A, would require similar customer validation . For example, Behrens Wu has displayed persistence, ingenuity, and an ability to secure funding. By researching the field and crafting eye-catching “cold” emails, she secured support and mentorship from prominent investors. Behrens Wu has also demonstrated a commitment to lean start-up principles by using an MVP to test her hypotheses and keeping her team small. Students may note that Shippo is addressing a large and attractive market, estimated by one seed investor at $360 billion (case p. 10). The firm also benefits from a favorable macro-economic context. In addition, Shippo has some business experience: Kreuz has an MBA and Behrens Wu studied in a graduate business program (case pp. 3-4).  Some students may question the concept of founder-market fit, arguing that founders can evolve alongside their companies and should not be limited to industries with which they are familiar. such as Quora and Stack Exchange, and can design marketing materials to make them developer-friendly (case p. 9).  In terms of product strategy, Shippo should amplify the value proposition of the API so that they are competing in areas beyond price, for example, by adding additional services like package tracking or insurance.  To spearhead this transformation to a developer-oriented strategy, Shippo might consider hiring an experienced computer scientist for an executive role such as chief of API or even chief technology officer. In that scenario, Kreuz might move into another role such as chief of product.  Wrap Up The instructor may want to wrap up the case discussion with the following closing insights: Founder-market fit can be subtle. While Behrens Wu may have lacked provable technical skills, she had the grit, courage, strategic skills, charisma, and persistence that start-up founders need to be successful in a highly competitive funding environment. Some call this the X factor; others refer to “force of nature” entrepreneurs. Whatever you call it, great founders don’t just have relevant experience and history but can also simply have huge amounts of hustle and other skills to achieve founder-market fit. Rapid customer growth can appear to indicate product-market fit, but may actually represent a false positive. In the case of Shippo, the team offered a strong value proposition and had a good delivery platform (channel), but as churn data shows, the initial product

This technical debt must be repaid in the future to align the product’s quality with customer expectations. Following the $2 million seed round, Shippo went on to raise $7 million in series A round led by Union Square Ventures (USV). Following the round, USV’s Albert Wenger joined the Shippo board of directors. By September 2016, 10,000 companies together shipped millions of packages using Shippo’s software each month. In addition, Shippo hired engineer Sin-Mei Tsai to serve as vice president of engineering and e-commerce marketer Mikhail Ledvich as head of marketing. In September 2016, Shippo had 28 employees, and offered both a dashboard app and an API, but had decided to focus more tightly on the API strategy as its main growth engine. In a 2016 blogpost, Behrens Wu reflected on the future of her company: “Raising this round is really about growing the company. question: How would you evaluate the founder-market fit of the team at Shippo? Could you provide specific details regarding their backgrounds?

answer: Equity dilution over time can vary greatly depending on the number of funding rounds and the amount of capital raised in each round. However, there are some general rules of thumb. For instance, in each round of financing, it's typical to avoid selling more than 20% of your company, which means you could expect around 20% dilution per round. However, this can sometimes be pushed to 25% or even 30% in some cases. It's also important to note that the dilution is a function of the amount of capital you raise and your post-money valuation. For example, if you were to raise $5M on a $50M post-money valuation, you would be selling 10% of the company and thus diluting yourself by 10%. Over the course of a startup's life, especially if it goes through multiple rounds of financing from pre-seed through Series A, B, C, and beyond, the cumulative dilution can be significant.

This post originally appeared on TechCrunch. Dilution. Or as industry insiders call it, “taking a haircut.” Everybody knows that when you raise money at a startup your ownership percentage of the company goes down. The goal is to have the value of the startup go up by enough that you own a smaller percentage of a much larger business and therefore your total personal value goes up. The simplest way to think about this is: If you own 20% of a $2 million company your stake is worth $400,000. If you raise a new round venture capital (say $2.5 million at a $7.5 million pre-money valuation, which is a $10 million post-money) you get diluted by 25% (2.5m / 10m). So you own 15% of the new company but that 15% is now worth $1.5 million or a gain of $1.1 million. But understanding how you’re likely to get diluted over time is a more difficult concept. And figuring out how much your equity may be worth over the course of a 5-year stint at a startup is even more complicated. I’ve had to simplify a bit, but to make it easier to understand I’ve teamed up with Jess Bachman at Visual.ly. If you want to see a view of the power of their work check out this Steve Jobs infographic. I’m a huge believer in Info Graphics and the ability to create deeper understanding of complicated topics through visual means. As “Big Data” becomes more pervasive the power to visualize will become increasingly important. And Jess is awesome at his trade. His personal blog with some great example is here.

finish—from pre-seed through Series A, B, C, and beyond—there is a typical rule of thumb that you should avoid selling more than 20% of your company in any single round of financing. That rule isn’t precise—perhaps you might push it to 25% or even 30% in some cases if you are really keen on the money and the financial partner, but generally this “rule of 20” holds. This matrix is a planning tool to help founders think through not only the amount of money you want (the x axis) but the implications on the dilution based on the valuation (the y axis) and the threshold beyond which you want to avoid. Thus, if the Chief founders really want to raise $20 million and execute on their more aggressive expansion plans, they need to convince investors that they are worth $100 million in post-money valuation in order to avoid violating the rule of 20% and suffering too much dilution at the series A—a tall order! How much do we raise now, later? There is the existential question of, should I be diluting my own stock in this company? And it's another reason to feel like you have to have traction, you have to believe that this money is going to 10x the business. expectations for portfolio companies change during the pandemic? 2 replies Last reply 2 years agoView thread September 29th, 2021 jbussgang  11:32 AM Let me address @onavon's question - and one that others have raised - about founder comp, dilution, and taking money off the table along the way. In my experience, because founders are subject to four year vesting like everyone else, there are thoughtful conversations about founder incentives 5+ years into a startup's life. We tend to arrange for annual stock option grants for both the founders and top team members so that their "hold" (i.e., the value of their unvested shares) continues to be a significant incentive. We also tend to encourage founders to take money off the table. My target is usually $2-4M after tax as it's enough to pay down the mortgage/buy a nice home, have money for kids' college, and be able to focus on going long. I recently bought $4M from one of my founder/CEOs who started the company when he was in college and had zero liquidity over 8 years of company-building despite his 20% stake now being worth $100m on paper. Another rule of thumb is to sell 5-10% of their total holdings. In general, founders get well taken care of if they're performing well. If you don't want accountability from investors or a board of directors that you have to answer to, you need to make the Rich vs. King trade off (aka The Founder's Dilemma). In tech, it's not much of a choice because you typically need to raise upfront

To build a wildly successful startup that scales, founders need to share their equity with investors and team members. How much equity is shared is the tricky question. [update: Adeo thought that I hadn’t quite explained easily enough why this creates a 3x liquidation preference so I agreed to expand. Only read this red bit if you didn’t quite follow the argument above. If somebody gives you money under a convertible debt note at a $2.5m valuation and another person funds you with convertible debt at $5m valuation (high resolution financing) and your equity round finally closes at a $10 million valuation … what technically happens? The most straightforward way to do the deal and what most people do is to issue the first investor 4 times more shares than the ultimate equity investor to adjust for the 4x discount in price (ie if I give you 4x the shares it’s the same as though you paid 25% of the price for the shares). The second investor gets 2x more shares (50% discount). So in the end they all end up with Series A stock priced at the exact same price (say, $1.5 per share) but investor 1 & 2 have more stock than investor 3. And if I weren’t simplifying the math, I’d show you that the first investors get even more shares since they have a discount to the next round. So as your initial investor at a $2.5m they now have 4x the stock and thus 4x the liquidation preferences (since each share has liquidation preferences on it).

Every VC knows that the amount you raise is often a proxy for your valuation. VCs in early stage round assume that you will likely take 20–25% dilution for your funding round so if you’re raising $8–10 million they will assume your expectation is $24 million pre at the low-end of the range ($8m x 4 = $32m post money with $8m capital injected buying 25% of the company) and $40 million pre at the high end ($10m x 5= $50m post money with $10m capital injected buying 20% or $40m pre). So when you say $8–10m is your goal and you aren’t at all thinking about your valuation know that a VC hears “$24–40 million pre-money valuation expectations.” Of course there are times where 15% dilution is more appropriate and other times it can be 33% but in a first meeting we’re just trying to establish general ranges for reasonableness. If you’ve only ever raised $500k, have limited revenue, have 7 people at your company and aren’t a serial entrepreneur it’s a pretty tall order to imagine going straight to $8–10 million unless your data is very compelling or you’ve otherwise become “hot.” If you’ve raised $3 million previously, have $250k in monthly recurring revenue and 23 staff an $8–10 million round might be more down the fairway.

Jeff Bussgang Determining the right amount of capital to raise is a function of a few factors that we have covered: First, what stage you are at with your venture and where you are in the product-market fit journey Second, how much time do you need to achieve the next major milestones that will get you to the next valuation inflection points. Finally, what will it cost you in terms of operating expenses and net cash outflows to run the company and the associated experiments for that amount of time? Add 3-6 months of cushion for failed experiments, iterations, and fundraising and you get to the amount of money you need to raise. In the case of Chief, they had two options and two different operating plans. These options are informed by (1) the likelihood that you can execute your plan; (2) the likelihood that you can raise the amount of money desired; and (3) the cost of capital in the form of dilution. Entering in a number of assumptions regarding the company’s post-money valuation allows you to draw out this dilution matrix: Post $ Valuation    Raise $5M    Raise $10M    Raise $15M    Raise $20M $40M                13%          25%           38%           50% $60M                8%           17%           25%           33% $80M                6%           13%           19%           25% $100M               5%           10%           15%           20% Most founders are dilution sensitive—rightfully so! They want to own as much of their company as possible. But remember my earlier reference to Rich vs. King? To build a wildly successful startup that scales, founders need to share their equity with investors and team members. How much equity is shared is the tricky question. Because founders know that there will be multiple rounds of financing from start to finish—from pre-seed through Series A, B, C, and beyond—there is a typical rule of thumb that you should avoid selling more than 20% of your company in any single round of financing. [update: Adeo thought that I hadn’t quite explained easily enough why this creates a 3x liquidation preference so I agreed to expand. Only read this red bit if you didn’t quite follow the argument above. If somebody gives you money under a convertible debt note at a $2.5m valuation and another person funds you with convertible debt at $5m valuation (high resolution financing) and your equity round finally closes at a $10 million valuation … what technically happens? The most straightforward way to do the deal and what most people do is to issue the first investor 4 times more shares than the ultimate equity investor to adjust for the 4x discount in price (ie if I give you 4x the shares it’s the same as though you paid 25% of the price for the shares). The second investor gets 2x more shares (50% discount). So in the end they all end up with Series A stock priced at the exact same price (say, $1.5 per share) but investor 1 & 2 have more stock than investor 3. And if I weren’t simplifying the math, I’d show you that the first investors get even more shares since they have a discount to the next round. So as your initial investor at a $2.5m they now have 4x the stock and thus 4x the liquidation preferences (since each share has liquidation preferences on it).
